text: Summary
label: HH3

text: Capitol Reef National Park (park), in cooperation with the Federal Highway Administration
label: BODY

text: (FHWA), Central Federal Lands Highway Division (CFLHD), proposes to rehabilitate and
label: BODY

text: resurface eight miles of the Scenic Drive roadway from the intersection with Utah State Route
label: BODY

text: 24 (SR-24) (milepost 0.0) and the parking lot for Capitol Gorge (milepost 8.0).
label: BODY

text: The proposal to rehabilitate and resurface the Scenic Drive is needed because the roadway
label: BODY

text: surface has deteriorated with signs of shoving and rutting, as well as deteriorated pavement
label: BODY

text: edges, potholes, and bleeding and cracking failures. Cracking of the pavement is common
label: BODY

text: within the travel lanes and along the shoulders. The roadway is threatened in some locations by
label: BODY

text: eroding ditches and drainage channels. Some culverts are plugged with debris. Numerous
label: BODY

text: culvert headwalls have become weakened because of erosion and deterioration of the mortar.
label: BODY

text: This environmental assessment evaluates two alternatives: a no-action alternative and an action
label: BODY

text: alternative. The no-action alternative describes the current road maintenance regimen of spot
label: BODY

text: repairs and chip-sealing of the roadway as needed, with periodic repairs to individual drainage
label: BODY

text: structures as the need arises. The park would respond to future needs and conditions without
label: BODY

text: substantial actions or changes in the present maintenance regimen.
label: BODY

text: Under the proposed alternative, Rehabilitate and Resurface the Scenic Drive, the roadway
label: BODY

text: would be rehabilitated and repaved with asphalt pavement or with chip-seal throughout its 8-
label: BODY

text: mile length. From the intersection with State Route 24, milepost (MP) 0.00, to the park fee
label: BODY

text: station at MP 1.70, the existing pavement on the Scenic Drive would be pulverized and the
label: BODY

text: roadway would be paved with asphalt concrete. Between the fee station and the Capitol Gorge
label: BODY

text: parking area the existing chip-seal pavement would be pulverized, and the roadway would be
label: BODY

text: paved with a double chip-seal overlay. Painted centerline striping would be applied from the
label: BODY

text: picnic area and campground in the Fruita Historic District to the intersection with SR-24.
label: BODY

text: Centerline striping may also be applied at some of the sharpest curves, to enhance safety.
label: BODY

text: Rumble strips would be installed at the beginning of the 15-mile-per-hour speed zone. Minor
label: BODY

text: improvements would be made to the Fruita Campground entrance to provide additional width for
label: BODY

text: turning movements into and out of the campground. Paved asphalt aprons would be developed
label: BODY

text: and extended into the entrances of Grand Wash and the Pleasant Creek Road.
label: BODY

text: Existing concrete low water crossings would be repaired or replaced in kind as needed. Cut
label: BODY

text: and fill slope erosion and slumping along the roadway would be repaired as needed. The
label: BODY

text: Capitol Gorge parking area would be paved with asphalt pavement. Some existing minor
label: BODY

text: parking areas and pullouts would be reconstructed and formalized. Vegetated areas disturbed
label: BODY

text: by construction activities would be revegetated with native plants and seeds. Existing roadway
label: BODY

text: signs would be replaced.
label: BODY

text: Damaged and deteriorating culverts (historic and non-historic) would be repaired and/or
label: BODY

text: reconstructed, and new culverts would be installed where needed. The NPS considers the
label: BODY

text: Scenic Drive as potentially eligible for listing in the National Register of Historic Places.
label: BODY

text: Therefore, all masonry stone rehabilitation would be completed in accordance with the
label: BODY

text: Secretary of the Interior’s Standards for the Preservation of Historic Properties. Consultation
label: BODY

text: with the Utah State Historic Preservation Office (SHPO) was conducted under a separate
label: BODY

text: United States Department of the Interior • National Park Service • Capitol Reef National Park
label: BODY

text: United States Department of the Interior • National Park Service • Capitol Reef National Park
label: BODY

text: submittal in compliance with Section 106 of the National Historic Preservation of 1966, as
label: BODY

text: amended.
label: BODY

text: This environmental assessment has been prepared in compliance with the National
label: BODY

text: Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) to provide the decision-making framework that 1) analyzes a
label: BODY

text: reasonable range of alternatives to meet objectives of the proposal, 2) evaluates potential
label: BODY

text: issues and impacts to Capitol Reef National Park’s resources and values, and 3) identifies
label: BODY

text: mitigation measures to lessen the degree or extent of these impacts. Resource topics analyzed
label: BODY

text: in detail in this document include cultural landscapes; soundscape; soils and geology; health
label: BODY

text: and safety; visitor use and experience; and park operations and management. All other
label: BODY

text: resource topics were dismissed because the project would have negligible or minor impacts on
label: BODY

text: those resources. No major impacts are anticipated as a result of this project.
label: BODY

text: PURPOSE AND NEED
label: HH1

text: Introduction
label: HH2

text: Capitol Reef National Park (park) is located in southern Utah in Wayne, Garfield, Sevier, and
label: BODY

text: Emery Counties, Utah. The headquarters area and the project areas are located east of the
label: BODY

text: town of Torrey, in Wayne County, Utah. Capitol Reef was first established as a national
label: BODY

text: monument on August 2, 1937 by Presidential Proclamation 2246 (50 Stat. 1856). The
label: BODY

text: monument originally comprised 37,060 acres. Additional lands were added to the monument by
label: BODY

text: Presidential Proclamation 3249 of July 2, 1958 and Presidential Proclamation 3888 of January
label: BODY

text: 20, 1969. On December 18, 1971, Congress abolished Capitol Reef National Monument and
label: BODY

text: established Capitol Reef National Park, with its final boundaries encompassing 241,903 acres
label: BODY

text: (85 Stat. 639, 16 U.S.C. §273 et seq.). The park is managed by the National Park Service.
label: BODY

text: This environmental assessment (EA) will examine the environmental impacts associated with
label: BODY

text: the proposal to repair and resurface the entire 8-mile length of the asphalt-paved and chip-
label: BODY

text: sealed Scenic Drive roadway between SR-24 and the parking lot for Capitol Gorge. This EA
label: BODY

text: was prepared in accordance with the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) of 1969,
label: BODY

text: regulations of the Council on Environmental Quality (CEQ) (40 CFR §1508.9), and the National
label: BODY

text: Park Service Director’s Order (DO)-12 (Conservation Planning, Environmental Impact Analysis,
label: BODY

text: and Decision-Making). Figure 1 depicts the location of the Scenic Drive.
label: BODY

text: Background
label: HH2

text: The Scenic Drive is a hard-surfaced road that extends between Utah State Road 24 (Utah SR-
label: BODY

text: 24) and Capitol Gorge. The narrow and twisting road, a popular driving route used by park
label: BODY

text: visitors, has numerous concrete-paved low water crossings that are sometimes impassable
label: BODY

text: during seasonal flash flooding. It connects with spur roads accessing popular hiking and scenic
label: BODY

text: locales, and it is the primary scenic tour road within the park. Much of the Scenic Drive was
label: BODY

text: chip-sealed in 1988. The improvements made the road more attractive to visitors in passenger
label: BODY

text: vehicles and motor homes, and traffic and use of trails in the area increased. The use of large
label: BODY

text: recreational vehicles on the narrow, winding, and shoulderless road has created safety
label: BODY

text: concerns. Cyclists and pedestrians, in combination with the large vehicles and other traffic, add
label: BODY

text: to those concerns.
label: BODY

text: Purpose and Need
label: HH2

text: The purpose of the proposal to repair and resurface the Scenic Drive between SR-24 and the
label: BODY

text: parking lot for Capitol Gorge is to maintain a safe and reliable roadway, while providing the
label: BODY

text: National Park Service (NPS) the opportunity to meet and uphold its mandate to administer and
label: BODY

text: protect the park for the enjoyment of natural, cultural, and scientific resources in a manner that
label: BODY

text: leaves these resources unimpaired.
label: BODY

text: The Scenic Drive is in need of repair. The roadway surface has deteriorated, with signs of
label: BODY

text: shoving and rutting, as well as deteriorated pavement edges, potholes, and bleeding and
label: BODY

text: cracking failures. Such damage occurs within the travel lanes in locations where the subgrade
label: BODY

text: becomes saturated because of poor drainage, and along the edges of the pavement where
label: BODY

text: there is little shoulder support. The roadway is threatened in some locations by eroding ditches
label: BODY

text: and drainage channels. Plugged or undersized culverts in some locations force seasonal runoff
label: BODY

text: to flow across the road, eroding the pavement and the roadway bench. Numerous stone
label: BODY

text: headwalls have become weakened and are threatened with failure, because of erosion and
label: BODY

text: deterioration of the mortar.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Poorly defined drainage ditches also cause roadway overtopping and roadway shoulder erosion
label: BODY

text: in some locations. Some concrete paved low water crossings have erosion damage. Figures 2
label: BODY

text: through 11 illustrate some of the repair needs.
label: BODY

text: The objectives of the proposed project are to:
label: BODY

text: Improve the Efficiency of Park Operations
label: BODY

text: Repair damaged and deteriorating road pavement, drainage, stone masonry
label: BODY

text: retaining walls, headwalls, and other structural features
label: BODY

text: Reduce maintenance requirements and costs due to deficiencies in the condition of
label: BODY

text: the road
label: BODY

text: Provide for Visitor Enjoyment and Safety
label: BODY

text: Improve the roadway condition to more safely accommodate traffic
label: BODY

text: Reduce the incidence and risk of traffic accidents
label: BODY

text: Efficiently implement rehabilitation work while minimizing visitor impact
label: BODY

text: Protect Park Resources
label: BODY

text: Maintain the scenic quality of the road
label: BODY

text: Protect park natural and cultural resources and values
label: BODY

text: Relationship to Other Plans and Policies
label: BODY

text: This proposal is consistent with the objectives of the Capitol Reef National Park Final
label: BODY

text: Environmental Impact Statement, General Management Plan, and Development Concept Plan
label: BODY

text: (1998), which outlines the management, use, and development of the Park through the year
label: BODY

text: 2013. The proposal is consistent with the 2006 National Park Service Management Policies goals
label: BODY

text: and objectives for natural resource and cultural resource management, use of the park,
label: BODY

text: transportation systems, park facilities, and visitor facilities.
label: BODY

text: It is consistent with the objectives of the 1984 NPS Park Roads Standards, which states that
label: BODY

text: roads in national parks serve a distinctly different purpose from most other road and highway
label: BODY

text: systems. Park roads are to be designed with extreme care and sensitivity to provide access for
label: BODY

text: the protection, use, and enjoyment of the resources that constitute the national park system.
label: BODY

text: It is consistent with Director’s Order – 87A, which states that park roads are constructed only
label: BODY

text: where necessary to provide access for the protection, use, and enjoyment of the natural,
label: BODY

text: historical, cultural, and recreational resources that constitute our national park system. Park
label: BODY

text: roads should enhance the visitor experience while providing safe and efficient accommodation
label: BODY

text: of park visitors and to serve essential management action needs. Park roads are designed with
label: BODY

text: extreme care and sensitivity with respect to the terrain and environment through which they
label: BODY

text: pass—they are laid lightly onto the land.
label: BODY

text: Appropriate Use
label: BODY

text: Section 1.5 of 2006 National Park Service Management Policies, “Appropriate Use of the Parks,”
label: BODY

text: directs that the National Park Service must ensure that park uses that are allowed would not
label: BODY

text: cause impairment of, or unacceptable impacts on, park resources and values. A form of park
label: BODY

text: use may be allowed within a park only after a determination has been made in the professional
label: BODY

text: judgment of the park manager that it will not result in unacceptable impacts.
label: BODY

text: Resurface the 8-Mile Scenic Drive Road Environmental Assessment
label: BODY

text: Capitol Reef National Park
label: BODY

text: Section 8.1.2 of 2006 National Park Service Management Policies, Process for Determining
label: BODY

text: Appropriate Uses, provides evaluation factors for determining appropriate uses. All proposals
label: BODY

text: for park uses are evaluated for:
label: BODY

text: consistency with applicable laws, executive orders, regulations, and policies;
label: BODY

text: consistency with existing plans for public use and resource management;
label: BODY

text: actual and potential effects on park resources and values;
label: BODY

text: total costs to the Service; and
label: BODY

text: whether the public interest will be served.
label: BODY

text: Park managers must continually monitor all park uses to prevent unanticipated and
label: BODY

text: unacceptable impacts. If unanticipated and unacceptable impacts emerge, the park manager
label: BODY

text: must engage in a thoughtful, deliberate process to further manage or constrain the use, or
label: BODY

text: discontinue it.
label: BODY

text: From Section 8.2 of 2006 National Park Service Management Policies: “To provide for enjoyment
label: BODY

text: of the parks, the National Park Service will encourage visitor use activities that
label: BODY

text: are appropriate to the purpose for which the park was established, and
label: BODY

text: are inspirational, educational, or healthful, and otherwise appropriate to the park
label: BODY

text: environment; and
label: BODY

text: will foster an understanding of and appreciation for park resources and values, or will
label: BODY

text: promote enjoyment through a direct association with, interaction with, or relation to park
label: BODY

text: resources; and
label: BODY

text: can be sustained without causing unacceptable impacts to park resources and values.
label: BODY

text: The Scenic Drive, in its present configuration, has been in continuous use since it was
label: BODY

text: constructed. The proposed rehabilitation of the Scenic Drive is consistent with the park’s
label: BODY

text: general management plan and other related park plans. The NPS finds that maintaining
label: BODY

text: automobile access along the Scenic Drive and to trailheads and other points of interest along
label: BODY

text: the road is an acceptable use at Capitol Reef National Park.
label: BODY

text: Scoping
label: BODY

text: Capitol Reef National Park conducted internal scoping with appropriate National Park Service
label: BODY

text: staff, as described in more detail in the Consultation and Coordination chapter. The park also
label: BODY

text: conducted external scoping with the State of Utah Historic Preservation Office and
label: BODY

text: interested/affected groups. More information regarding external scoping can be found in
label: BODY

text: Comments and Coordination.

text: Impact Topics Retained for Further Analysis
label: BODY

text: In this section and the following section on Impact Topics Dismissed from Further Analysis, the
label: BODY

text: NPS analyzes all potential impacts by considering the direct, indirect, and cumulative effects of
label: BODY

text: the proposed action on the environment, along with connected and cumulative actions. Impacts
label: BODY

text: are described in terms of context and duration. The context or extent of the impact is described
label: BODY

text: as localized or widespread. The duration of impacts is described as short-term or long-term. The
label: BODY

text: intensity and type of impact is described as negligible, minor, moderate, or major, and as
label: BODY

text: beneficial or adverse. The NPS equates “major” effects as “significant” effects. The identification
label: BODY

text: of “major” effects would trigger the need for an EIS. Where the intensity of an impact could be
label: BODY

text: described quantitatively, the numerical data are presented; however, most impact analyses are
label: BODY

text: qualitative and use best professional judgment in making the assessment.
label: BODY

text: If there is no effect or no measurable effect, there would either be no contribution to cumulative
label: BODY

text: effects, or the contribution would be low. For each issue or topic presented below, if the
label: BODY

text: resource is found in the analysis area or the issue is applicable to the proposal, then a limited
label: BODY

text: analysis of direct and indirect, and cumulative effects is presented. There is no impairment
label: BODY

text: analysis included in the limited evaluations for the dismissed topics because the NPS’s
label: BODY

text: threshold for considering whether there could be an impairment is based on “major” effects.
label: BODY

text: Impact topics for this project have been identified on the basis of federal laws, regulations, and
label: BODY

text: orders; 2006 National Park Service Management Policies; and National Park Service knowledge
label: BODY

text: of resources at Capitol Reef National Park. Impact topics that are carried forward for further
label: BODY

text: analysis in this EA are listed below along with the reasons why the impact topic is further
label: BODY

text: analyzed.
label: BODY

text: Cultural Landscapes
label: BODY

text: According to the Director’s Order # 28, “Cultural Resource Management Guideline,” a cultural
label: BODY

text: landscape is  “. . . a reflection of human adaptation and use of natural resources and is often
label: BODY

text: expressed in the way land is organized and divided, patterns of settlement, land use, systems of
label: BODY

text: circulation, and the types of structures that are built. The character of a cultural landscape is
label: BODY

text: defined by both physical materials, such as roads, buildings, walls, and vegetation, and by use
label: BODY

text: reflecting cultural values.”
label: BODY

text: The NPS has identified the Scenic Drive/Capitol Gorge landscape as potentially eligible for
label: BODY

text: listing in the National Register of Historic Places. Constructed in 1883, the road now known as
label: BODY

text: the Scenic Drive was little more than a wagon trail that connected the farming community of
label: BODY

text: Fruita to Torrey, Notom and other communities nearby. Prior to the rerouting and paving of a
label: BODY

text: section of Utah Highway 24 through Fremont Canyon in 1962, the old route south of Fruita
label: BODY

text: through Capitol Gorge (now part of the Scenic Drive) was the main road through the
label: BODY

text: Waterpocket Fold, a route formerly used by Native Americans for centuries. Fruita, a Mormon
label: BODY

text: farming community, was founded in 1880. The northern 1.7-mile section of the Scenic Drive that
label: BODY

text: passes through the community is considered a contributing feature of the Fruita Rural Historic
label: BODY

text: District, which was listed in the National Register of Historic Places in 1997.
label: BODY

text: Properties more than fifty years old may be eligible for the National Register if they meet the
label: BODY

text: criteria for listing and for contributions at the national, state, or local level. In order for a property
label: BODY

text: to be listed in the National Register, it also must possess historic integrity of those features
label: BODY

text: necessary to convey its significance, i.e., location, design, setting, workmanship, materials,
label: BODY

text: feeling, and association. The Fruita landscape was determined eligible because its original land
label: BODY

text: use patterns, particularly its historic fruit orchards, remain relatively intact. The Fruita Historic
label: BODY

text: Resurface the 8-Mile Scenic Drive Road Environmental Assessment
label: BODY

text: Capitol Reef National Park
label: BODY

text: District landscape also contains 14 historic buildings, including a schoolhouse, two homes,
label: BODY

text: outbuildings and cellars, and a distilling site.
label: BODY

text: In the early 1940s, the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) completed improvements to the
label: BODY

text: Scenic Drive, including construction of culverts and other drainage features. However, historic
label: BODY

text: records do not indicate how many of these features pre-dated the CCC era. It is unclear which
label: BODY

text: drainage features date to the CCC era, and which were constructed earlier and simply repaired
label: BODY

text: or rebuilt between 1938 and 1942. The Scenic Drive currently has 64 culverts and 22 low water
label: BODY

text: crossings. An inventory of culverts completed by park staff in 2009 identified six that are known
label: BODY

text: or are likely to have been constructed by the CCC, in addition to another 31 possible CCC-era
label: BODY

text: drainage features. Alterations were subsequently made to the road during the later Mission 66
label: BODY

text: period of NPS development (1945-1967), but the overall historic alignment and drainage
label: BODY

text: structures of the road remain relatively intact. The proposed Scenic Drive rehabilitation project
label: BODY

text: described in this EA would have the potential to impact the historic features of the Scenic Drive
label: BODY

text: and Fruita landscapes. For these reasons, the topic of cultural landscapes has been carried
label: BODY

text: forward for further analysis in this document.
label: BODY

text: Soundscape
label: BODY

text: Soundscape refers to the total ambient acoustic environment associated with a given
label: BODY

text: environment (sonic environment) in an area such as a national park. It is also refers to the total
label: BODY

text: ambient sound level for the park. In a national park setting, this soundscape is usually
label: BODY

text: composed of both natural ambient sounds and a variety of human-made sounds.
label: BODY

text: In accordance with 2006 National Park Service Management Policies and Director’s Order 47 –
label: BODY

text: Sound Preservation and Noise Management, an important component of the National Park
label: BODY

text: Service’s mission is the preservation of natural soundscapes associated with national park
label: BODY

text: units. Natural soundscapes exist in the absence of human-caused sound. The natural ambient
label: BODY

text: soundscape is the aggregate of all the natural sounds that occur in a park unit, together with the
label: BODY

text: physical capacity for transmitting natural sounds.
label: BODY

text: With either alternative discussed in this EA, human-caused noise, caused by visitors and their
label: BODY

text: vehicles as well as by park maintenance activities, would intrude upon the natural soundscape.
label: BODY

text: The preferred alternative would result in more construction noise than the no action alternative.
label: BODY

text: The majority of construction noise would occur from April to October. Effects to the natural
label: BODY

text: soundscape during daylight hours would be clearly detectable, localized, and periodic.
label: BODY

text: Therefore, soundscape was addressed as an impact topic in this EA.
label: BODY

text: Geology and Soils
label: BODY

text: According to the 2006 National Park Service Management Policies, the National Park Service will
label: BODY

text: preserve and protect geologic resources and features from adverse effects of human activity,
label: BODY

text: while allowing natural processes to continue (NPS 2006). These policies also state that the
label: BODY

text: National Park Service will strive to understand and preserve the soil resources of park units and
label: BODY

text: to prevent, to the extent possible, the unnatural erosion, physical removal, or contamination of
label: BODY

text: the soil, or its contamination of other resources.
label: BODY

text: The proposed repairs and rehabilitation of the Scenic Drive would be mostly confined to the
label: BODY

text: existing road bench, but some excavation would be needed to widen the roadway in a few
label: BODY

text: locations to achieve a consistent width, and to widen some sharp “S-shaped” curves to improve
label: BODY

text: safety. The proposed project would also require excavation in selected areas under the road
label: BODY

text: surface to reconstruct the subgrade, displacing and disturbing soils. Soils would also be
label: BODY

text: disturbed and compacted in one of the staging areas.

text: Health and Safety
label: BODY

text: The NPS is committed to providing appropriate, high-quality opportunities for visitors and
label: BODY

text: employees to enjoy the parks in a safe and healthful environment. The goals of the park include
label: BODY

text: ensuring that basic visitor needs are met in keeping with the park purposes, and that visitor and
label: BODY

text: employee safety and health are protected. To the extent feasible, facilities, programs, and
label: BODY

text: services in the park are accessible to and usable by all people, including those with disabilities
label: BODY

text: One of the primary purposes of this proposed project is to improve safety. The NPS also wants
label: BODY

text: to keep the roadway and associated park resources open during construction and, as a result,
label: BODY

text: protective measures need to be studied and implemented to ensure safety to motorists and
label: BODY

text: visitors. Because the proposed project would affect health and safety of park staff and visitors,
label: BODY

text: this topic has been carried forward for further analysis.
label: BODY

text: Visitor Use and Experience
label: BODY

text: According to 2006 National Park Service Management Policies, the enjoyment of park resources
label: BODY

text: and values by people is part of the fundamental purpose of all park units (NPS 2006). The
label: BODY

text: National Park Service is committed to providing appropriate, high quality opportunities for
label: BODY

text: visitors to enjoy the parks, and will maintain within the parks an atmosphere that is open,
label: BODY

text: inviting, and accessible to every segment of society. Further, the National Park Service will
label: BODY

text: provide opportunities for forms of enjoyment that are uniquely suited and appropriate to the
label: BODY

text: superlative natural and cultural resources found in the parks. The 2006 National Park Service
label: BODY

text: Management Policies also state that scenic views and visual resources are considered highly
label: BODY

text: valued associated characteristics that the National Park Service should strive to protect (NPS
label: BODY

text: Taking a self-guided tour of the Scenic Drive is one of the principal activities available to park
label: BODY

text: visitors. The average number of visitors who travel the Scenic Drive annually is around 70,000.
label: BODY

text: The average visitor length of stay for people who travel to the visitor center and the Scenic Drive
label: BODY

text: is 3 hours. Those who opt for the self-guided tour along the Scenic Drive are able to travel
label: BODY

text: through the historic settlement of Fruita and stop at eleven locations along the western face of
label: BODY

text: the Waterpocket Fold that offer spectacular scenic views of notable geologic formations. The
label: BODY

text: Scenic Drive also offers access to exploration of Grand Wash and Capitol Gorge. Because the
label: BODY

text: proposed project would affect visitor use and experience of these park resources, this topic has
label: BODY

text: been carried forward for further analysis.

text: Park Operations and Management
label: BODY

text: Park operations and management would be affected by implementation of either the no-action
label: BODY

text: alternative or the action alternative (alternative B). Either alternative would require repair and
label: BODY

text: maintenance activities on the Scenic Drive. Construction activities on the Scenic Drive would
label: BODY

text: require temporary changes in park operations to address traffic control and keep the public
label: BODY

text: informed about road conditions. Therefore, the topic of park operations has been carried
label: BODY

text: forward for further analysis in this document.

text: Vegetation and Invasive Exotic Plants
label: BODY

text: According to the 2006 National Park Service Management Policies, the National Park Service
label: BODY

text: strives to maintain all components and processes of naturally evolving park unit ecosystems,
label: BODY

text: including the natural abundance, diversity, and ecological integrity of plants (NPS 2006).
label: BODY

text: Construction activities on the roadway shoulders and immediately adjacent areas would
label: BODY

text: displace native vegetation and would provide conditions favorable for the establishment of
label: BODY

text: invasive exotic plants, but the impacts would be mitigated by control measures, such as a
label: BODY

text: revegetation plan, restricting construction activities to specified areas, and other mitigation
label: BODY

text: measures identified in this EA. The impacts would be negligible to minor, because the areas
label: BODY

text: where conditions would be favorable for invasion by exotic plants would be relatively small,
label: BODY

text: including the road shoulders and areas immediately adjacent to the roadway. The impacts
label: BODY

text: would be short-term because those areas would be revegetated with native species and the
label: BODY

text: spread of invasive exotic plants would be controlled.
label: BODY

text: Such negligible or minor impacts would not result in any unacceptable impacts; the proposed
label: BODY

text: actions are consistent with §1.4.7.1 of 2006 National Park Service Management Policies.
label: BODY

text: Because these effects are minor or less in degree and would not result in any unacceptable
label: BODY

text: impacts, this topic is dismissed from further analysis in this document.
label: BODY

text: Wildlife
label: BODY

text: The NPS Organic Act, which directs parks to conserve wildlife unimpaired for future
label: BODY

text: generations, is interpreted by the NPS to mean that native animal life should be protected and
label: BODY

text: perpetuated as part of the park’s natural ecosystem. Natural processes are relied on to control
label: BODY

text: populations of native species to the greatest extent possible; otherwise they are protected from
label: BODY

text: harm by human activities. Management goals for wildlife include maintaining components and
label: BODY

text: processes of naturally evolving park ecosystems, including natural abundance, diversity, and
label: BODY

text: the ecological integrity of plants and animals.
label: BODY

text: Wildlife commonly found in the proposed project area include mule deer, coyotes, bighorn
label: BODY

text: sheep, marmots, fox, woodrats, ringtails, chipmunks, ground squirrels, jackrabbits, bats,
label: BODY

text: kangaroo rats, mice, and many species of birds. There are also numerous insect species,
label: BODY

text: amphibians, and reptiles.
label: BODY

text: Neither of the alternatives would impact the overall abundance, diversity, or ecological integrity
label: BODY

text: of animals, nor inhibit the processes of park ecosystems. Wildlife habitat would be adversely
label: BODY

text: affected adjacent to the road along its length, e.g. through the removal of vegetation and soils.
label: BODY

text: Those impacts would be measurable, but they would not affect native species’ populations or
label: BODY

text: the natural processes sustaining them, beyond their natural range of variability. Mitigation
label: BODY

text: measures, such as replanting disturbed areas with native vegetation, would be in accordance
label: BODY

text: with conventional best management practices, and would have a high likelihood of success. The
label: BODY

text: long-term adverse impact to wildlife would be minor.
label: BODY

text: Resurface the 8-Mile Scenic Drive Road Environmental Assessment
label: BODY

text: Capitol Reef National Park
label: BODY

text: During construction, noise would also increase, which may disturb wildlife in the general area.
label: BODY

text: Construction-related noise would be temporary, and existing sound conditions would resume
label: BODY

text: following construction activities. Therefore, the temporary noise from construction would have a
label: BODY

text: negligible to minor adverse effect on wildlife.
label: BODY

text: Such negligible to minor impacts would not result in any unacceptable impacts; the proposed
label: BODY

text: actions are consistent with §1.4.7.1 of 2006 National Park Service Management Policies.
label: BODY

text: Because these effects are minor or less in degree and would not result in any unacceptable
label: BODY

text: impacts, this topic is dismissed from further analysis in this document.

text: Special Status Species
label: BODY

text: For federally sponsored projects, the Endangered Species Act (Act) of 1973 (as amended)
label: BODY

text: requires examination of potential impacts to Threatened, Endangered, and Candidate Species.
label: BODY

text: Section 7 of the Act requires federal agencies to ensure that any activities they authorize, fund,
label: BODY

text: or implement, do not jeopardize the continued existence of any wildlife species federally listed
label: BODY

text: as threatened or endangered and do not destroy or adversely modify designated critical habitat.
label: BODY

text: NPS policy requires examination of potential impacts on federal candidate species, as well as
label: BODY

text: state-listed threatened, endangered, candidate, rare, declining, and sensitive species with
label: BODY

text: potential to occur within the project area. For simplicity, the federal and state-listed species
label: BODY

text: identified in this EA are collectively described as Special Status Species.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: the vicinity of the Scenic Drive. Park staff have determined that those plants will not be affected
label: BODY

text: by the proposed repair and rehabilitation of the Scenic Drive.

text: A portion of the proposed project area lies within designated critical habitat for the Mexican
label: BODY

text: spotted owl, and is near a protected activity center (PAC). The PAC has historically been
label: BODY

text: occupied by young and adult owls. However, a nest site has never been found. The most recent
label: BODY

text: detection of a Mexican spotted owl in the area was in1996, when a single male was observed.
label: BODY

text: Subsequent surveys were conducted in 1997, 2001, 2008, and 2009; no owls have been
label: BODY

text: detected. Based upon those survey data, construction activities associated with the proposed
label: BODY

text: project would not be expected to affect nesting or roosting Mexican spotted owls. Construction
label: BODY

text: activities are not expected to adversely affect any of the primary constituent elements of the
label: BODY

text: critical habitat or to adversely modify critical habitat.  In a letter dated December 3, 2009 the
label: BODY

text: NPS provided a list of federally listed and candidate species that could potentially occur in the
label: BODY

text: project area to the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS), and sought concurrence that the
label: BODY

text: proposed action would not adversely affect listed or candidate species or proposed or
label: BODY

text: designated critical habitat. The USFWS concurred on December 15, 2009 that the proposed
label: BODY

text: Resurface the 8-Mile Scenic Drive Road Environmental Assessment
label: BODY

text: Capitol Reef National Park
label: BODY

text: action was "not likely to adversely affect" any listed species, including Mexican spotted owls.
label: BODY

text: The NPS consultation and the USFWS concurrence are presented in Appendix A of this EA. No
label: BODY

text: adverse impacts to Threatened and Endangered Species would be anticipated with
label: BODY

text: implementation of the proposed action, and the proposed action would not result in any
label: BODY

text: unacceptable impacts. The proposed actions are consistent with §1.4.7.1 of 2006 National Park
label: BODY

text: Service Management Policies. Because there would be no adverse impacts or any unacceptable
label: BODY

text: impacts, this topic is dismissed from further analysis.

text: Water Resources
label: BODY

text: National Park Service policies require protection of water quality consistent with the Clean
label: BODY

text: Water Act. The purpose of the Clean Water Act is to "restore and maintain the chemical,
label: BODY

text: physical, and biological integrity of the Nation's waters."  To enact this goal, the U.S. Army
label: BODY

text: Corps of Engineers has been charged with evaluating federal actions that result in potential
label: BODY

text: degradation of waters of the United States and issuing permits for actions consistent with the
label: BODY

text: Clean Water Act. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency also has responsibility for
label: BODY

text: oversight and review of permits and actions, which affect waters of the United States.
label: BODY

text: The Scenic Drive crosses the Fremont River at one location in the Fruita Historic District, but the
label: BODY

text: rest of the proposed project area does not contain surface waters. It is mostly dry, except for
label: BODY

text: periodic flooding during sudden storm events.
label: BODY

text: A National Pollution Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit would be prepared by
label: BODY

text: CFLHD and submitted to the Utah Division of Water Quality prior to commencing any near-
label: BODY

text: water activities. As authorized by the Clean Water Act, the NPDES permit program controls
label: BODY

text: water pollution by regulating conveyances such as pipes or man-made ditches that discharge
label: BODY

text: pollutants into waters of the United States.
label: BODY

text: A hazardous spill plan would be required from the contractor prior to the start of construction
label: BODY

text: stating what actions would be taken in the case of a spill and preventive measures to be
label: BODY

text: implemented. Hazardous spill clean-up materials would be on-site at all times.
label: BODY

text: Because of the mitigation benefits of the NPDES permit and a hazardous spill plan, and
label: BODY

text: because most of the Scenic Drive is well removed from surface waters, the impacts to water
label: BODY

text: quality and drinking water would be negligible. Water quantity would not be affected. Because
label: BODY

text: the effects on water resources would be no greater than negligible and would not result in any
label: BODY

text: unacceptable impacts, the topic is dismissed from further analysis in this document.
label: BODY

text: Wetlands
label: BODY

text: For the purpose of implementing Executive Order 11990 Protection of Wetlands, any area that
label: BODY

text: is classified as a wetland according to the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's "Classification of
label: BODY

text: Wetlands and Deepwater Habitats of the United States" (Cowardin et al. 1979) is subject to
label: BODY

text: Director’s Order #77-1: Wetland Protection (D.O. 77-1) and its implementation procedures as
label: BODY

text: presented in Procedural Manual #77-1: Wetland Protection (2008). The Cowardin classification
label: BODY

text: system forms the basis for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's National Wetlands Inventory
label: BODY

text: (NWI) mapping program. Under the Cowardin definition, a wetland must have one or more of
label: BODY

text: the following three attributes:
label: BODY

text: 1. at least periodically, the land supports predominantly hydrophytes (wetland vegetation);
label: BODY

text: 2. the substrate is predominantly undrained hydric soil; or
label: BODY

text: 3. the substrate is non-soil and is saturated with water or covered by shallow water at some time
label: BODY

text: during the growing season of each year.
label: BODY

text: Resurface the 8-Mile Scenic Drive Road Environmental Assessment
label: BODY

text: Capitol Reef National Park
label: BODY

text: Most of the dry washes within the project area meet the third attribute listed above, and
label: BODY

text: therefore are considered wetlands.
label: BODY

text: Channels or similar features that are used for the sole purpose of active stormwater or
label: BODY

text: wastewater are not considered wetlands for purposes of Procedural Manual #77-1. Therefore,
label: BODY

text: drainage ditches alongside the Scenic Drive road bed are not considered wetlands.
label: BODY

text: Executive Order 11990 requires federal agencies to avoid, where possible, adversely impacting
label: BODY

text: wetlands. Further, §404 of the Clean Water Act authorizes the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to
label: BODY

text: prohibit or regulate, through a permitting process, discharge of dredged or fill material or
label: BODY

text: excavation within waters of the United States. National Park Service policies for wetlands, as
label: BODY

text: stated in 2006 National Park Service Management Policies and D.O. 77-1 strive to prevent the
label: BODY

text: loss or degradation of wetlands and to preserve and enhance the natural and beneficial values
label: BODY

text: of wetlands. In accordance with D.O. 77-1, proposed actions that have the potential to adversely
label: BODY

text: impact wetlands must be addressed in a statement of findings for wetlands.
label: BODY

text: Some actions may be excepted from the statement of findings and compensation requirements
label: BODY

text: (D.O. 77-1, 4.2.1). They include maintenance, repair, or renovation (but not full reconstruction or
label: BODY

text: expansion) of currently serviceable facilities or structures:
label: BODY

text: - that were under construction or were completed prior to May 28, 1980, but whose retention
label: BODY

text: has been reviewed and justified, or
label: BODY

text: - that were completed after publication of the May 28, 1980 guidelines, and for which
label: BODY

text: compliance with them is on record.
label: BODY

text: This exception allows for minor deviations (total of 0.1 acre or less throughout the entire project)
label: BODY

text: in the structure's configuration or fill footprint in wetlands due to subsequent changes in
label: BODY

text: construction codes, methods, or safety standards (e.g., handicap accessibility), but does not
label: BODY

text: apply to other types of reconstruction/expansion (e.g., road widening to increase capacity, road
label: BODY

text: re-routing) or conversion to other uses that would have additional adverse impacts on wetlands.
label: BODY

text: In order to eliminate future erosion, which could create scour holes, it is anticipated that outlet
label: BODY

text: protection would be constructed below drain outfalls in some naturally-occurring dry washes.
label: BODY

text: Some of the washes meet the Cowardin definition of riverine intermittent wetlands. Such dry
label: BODY

text: washes are common throughout the park and the geographic area. The outlet protection
label: BODY

text: features would vary in size, depending on conditions in the washes. The outlet protection
label: BODY

text: features might incorporate stone riprap or concrete in colors matching the surrounding soil.
label: BODY

text: The FHWA estimated in the October 5, 2009 Preliminary Design Study Report – Draft, Appendix
label: BODY

text: C, that less than 0.1 acre would be impacted by construction of outlet protection in the washes.
label: BODY

text: Because the repair and rehabilitation of the Scenic drive would adversely impact less than 0.1
label: BODY

text: acre of wetlands, and because the impacts of the proposed work meet the conditions in
label: BODY

text: Appendix 2 of D.O. 77-1, that rehabilitation work would be an excepted action. Therefore, it will
label: BODY

text: not be necessary to prepare a wetland statement of findings as part of this environmental
label: BODY

text: assessment, and compensation for the wetland impacts will not be required.
label: BODY

text: The adverse effects on wetlands would be minor or less. They would be detectable, but
label: BODY

text: relatively small in terms of area and the nature of the change. The action would affect a limited
label: BODY

text: number of individuals of plant or wildlife species within the wetland, but all species would remain
label: BODY

text: viable. Because the effects would be no greater than minor and would not result in any
label: BODY

text: unacceptable impacts, this topic has been dismissed from further analysis in this document.

text: Floodplains
label: BODY

text: Executive Order 11988 Floodplain Management requires all federal agencies to avoid
label: BODY

text: construction within the 100-year floodplain unless no other practicable alternative exists. The
label: BODY

text: National Park Service under 2006 National Park Service Management Policies and Director’s
label: BODY

text: Order 77-2 Floodplain Management will strive to preserve floodplain values and minimize
label: BODY

text: hazardous floodplain conditions. According to Director’s Order 77-2 Floodplain Management,
label: BODY

text: certain construction within a 100-year floodplain requires preparation of a statement of findings
label: BODY

text: for floodplains.
label: BODY

text: A floodplain statement of findings was completed for the park GMP EIS in 1998 (NPS 1998,
label: BODY

text: Appendix F), based on mapping of the Fruita area in 1995. The northern portion of the Scenic
label: BODY

text: Drive from the picnic area to the Gifford barn is within the 100-year floodplain. Areas to the
label: BODY

text: south have not been mapped. However, the Scenic Drive is considered an excepted action
label: BODY

text: under the NPS final procedures for implementing Executive Order 11988, because the section
label: BODY

text: of the Scenic Drive that passes through the Fruita area is considered a contributing feature of
label: BODY

text: the Fruita Rural Historic District, which was listed in the National Register of Historic Places in
label: BODY

text: 1997. The NPS also considers the Scenic Drive/Capitol Gorge as a separate component
label: BODY

text: landscape within the park that is potentially eligible for listing in the National Register of Historic
label: BODY

text: Places. The Floodplain Management manual does not apply to historic structures whose
label: BODY

text: location is integral to their significance.
label: BODY

text: Pavement pulverization and road repaving within the existing roadway footprint, and repairs to
label: BODY

text: culverts and low water crossings would be the only work on the floodplain. There would be no
label: BODY

text: change in the ability of a floodplain to convey floodwaters, or its values and functions. The
label: BODY

text: proposed project would not contribute to flooding. The proposed project would not result in
label: BODY

text: significant or unacceptable impacts to floodplain values, and the proposed actions are
label: BODY

text: consistent with §1.4.7.1 of 2006 National Park Service Management Policies. Therefore, this
label: BODY

text: topic is dismissed from further analysis in this document.
label: BODY

text: Historic structures
label: BODY

text: There are 14 historic structures within the park. Only one of these, the Gifford barn, is situated
label: BODY

text: in close proximity to the Scenic Drive within the Fruita Rural Historic District. The structure is
label: BODY

text: separated from the road by a non-historic post-and-rail fence (see Figure 5). The barn is
label: BODY

text: associated with the Gifford farm complex, which was constructed circa 1900. It is a rectangular,
label: BODY

text: post-and-beam building with vertical plank siding.
label: BODY

text: The proposed road work may include resetting two fence posts in proximity to the Gifford Barn
label: BODY

text: to allow for a clear zone at the road shoulder. However, there would be negligible impacts to the
label: BODY

text: setting of this historic structure. Because these effects are less than minor in degree and would
label: BODY

text: not result in unacceptable impacts, this topic is dismissed from further analysis in this document.

text: Archeological Resources
label: BODY

text: In August 2009, a Phase I archeological survey of the Scenic Drive was completed (Bonnifield
label: BODY

text: 2009). A total of eight sites were recorded in proximity to the Scenic Drive; two are considered
label: BODY

text: eligible for listing in the National Register of Historic Places. However, the proposed road
label: BODY

text: construction activities are not expected to impact archeological resources because construction
label: BODY

text: activities would be confined to the road bench and designated staging areas. In addition, all
label: BODY

text: construction activities conducted in proximity to the two National Register-eligible sites would be
label: BODY

text: monitored by a professional archeologist.

text: Ethnographic Resources
label: BODY

text: National Park Service’s Director’s Order-28 Cultural Resource Management defines
label: BODY

text: ethnographic resources as any site, structure, object, landscape, or natural resource feature
label: BODY

text: assigned traditional legendary, religious, subsistence, or other significance in the cultural
label: BODY

text: system of a group traditionally associated with it. According to DO-28 and Executive Order
label: BODY

text: 13007 on sacred sites, the National Park Service should try to preserve and protect
label: BODY

text: ethnographic resources.
label: BODY

text: Ethnographic resources are not known to exist in the proposed project area. Native American
label: BODY

text: tribes traditionally associated with the park will receive copies of this document for their review
label: BODY

text: and comment. If subsequent issues or concerns are identified, appropriate consultations will be
label: BODY

text: undertaken. Because these effects are less than minor in degree and would not result in any
label: BODY

text: unacceptable impacts, this topic is dismissed from further analysis in this document.

text: Museum Collections
label: BODY

text: Museum collections include historic artifacts, natural specimens, and archival and manuscript
label: BODY

text: material. They may be threatened by fire, vandalism, natural disasters, and careless acts. The
label: BODY

text: National Park Service requires the consideration of impacts on museum collections (historic
label: BODY

text: artifacts, natural specimens, and archival and manuscript material), and provides further policy
label: BODY

text: guidance, standards, and requirements for preserving, protecting, documenting, and providing
label: BODY

text: access to, and use of, National Park Service museum collections. The proposed activities would
label: BODY

text: not require additional curatorial services or increase the number of museum objects at the park;
label: BODY

text: therefore, museum objects were dismissed from further analysis in this document.
label: BODY

text: Air Quality
label: BODY

text: The Clean Air Act of 1963 (42 U.S.C. 7401 et seq.) was established to promote the public health
label: BODY

text: and welfare by protecting and enhancing the nation’s air quality. The act establishes specific
label: BODY

text: programs that provide special protection for air resources and air quality related values
label: BODY

text: associated with National Park Service units. Section 118 of the Clean Air Act requires a park
label: BODY

text: unit to meet all federal, state, and local air pollution standards. Capitol Reef National Park is
label: BODY

text: designated as a Class I air quality area under the Clean Air Act. A Class I area is subject to the
label: BODY

text: most stringent regulations of any designation, and must not exceed the maximum allowable
label: BODY

text: increment over baseline concentrations of sulfur dioxide and particulate matter as specified in
label: BODY

text: Section 163 of the 1963 Clean Air Act. Further, the Act provides that the federal land manager
label: BODY

text: has an affirmative responsibility to protect air quality related values (including visibility, plants,
label: BODY

text: animals, soils, water quality, cultural resources, and visitor health) from adverse pollution
label: BODY

text: impacts (EPA 2000). The air quality at Capitol Reef is generally very good; occasionally,
label: BODY

text: particulate levels in the area are high due to high winds, as is typical in a desert environment.
label: BODY

text: Construction activities such as hauling materials and operating heavy equipment could result in
label: BODY

text: temporary increases of vehicle exhaust, emissions, and fugitive dust in the general project area.
label: BODY

text: Resurface the 8-Mile Scenic Drive Road Environmental Assessment

label: BODY

text: During construction the contractor would be required to implement dust control mitigation
label: BODY

text: procedures to reduce the particulate matter. Additional mitigation measures that would be
label: BODY

text: implemented include: allowing construction vehicles to idle up to but not exceeding 5 minutes
label: BODY

text: when parked. Any exhaust, emissions, and fugitive dust generated from construction activities
label: BODY

text: would be temporary and localized and would likely dissipate rapidly because air stagnation at
label: BODY

text: Capitol Reef National Park is rare. Overall, the project could result in a negligible degradation of
label: BODY

text: local air quality, and such effects would be temporary, lasting only as long as construction. The
label: BODY

text: Class I air quality designation for Capitol Reef National Park would not be affected by the
label: BODY

text: proposal. Because the Class I air quality would not be affected and the proposed actions are
label: BODY

text: consistent with §1.4.7.1 of 2006 National Park Service Management Policies, and because there
label: BODY

text: would negligible effects on air quality, this topic is dismissed from further analysis in this
label: BODY

text: document.

text: Lightscape Management
label: BODY

text: In accordance with 2006 National Park Service Management Policies, the National Park Service
label: BODY

text: strives to preserve natural ambient lightscapes, which are natural resources and values that
label: BODY

text: exist in the absence of human caused light (NPS 2006). Capitol Reef National Park strives to
label: BODY

text: limit the use of artificial outdoor lighting to that which is necessary for basic safety requirements.
label: BODY

text: The park also strives to ensure that all outdoor lighting is shielded to the maximum extent
label: BODY

text: possible, to keep light on the intended subject and out of the night sky.
label: BODY

text: The current impact of light pollution along the Scenic Drive is localized and negligible, lasting as
label: BODY

text: long as it takes for a vehicle to pass. No additional artificial lighting or any actions that would
label: BODY

text: increase nighttime visitors are proposed under the preferred alternative. Further, such impacts
label: BODY

text: are negligible in degree. Because the effects are negligible and would not result in any
label: BODY

text: unacceptable impacts, this topic is dismissed from further analysis in this document.
label: BODY

text: Socioeconomics
label: BODY

text: The proposed action would neither change local and regional land use nor appreciably impact
label: BODY

text: local businesses or other agencies. Implementation of the proposed action could provide a
label: BODY

text: negligible beneficial impact to the economy of the gateway community of Torrey and Wayne
label: BODY

text: County due to minimal increases in employment opportunities for the construction workforce
label: BODY

text: and revenues for local businesses and governments generated from these additional
label: BODY

text: construction activities and workers. Any increase in workforce and revenue, however, would be
label: BODY

text: temporary and negligible, lasting only as long as construction. Because the impacts to the
label: BODY

text: socioeconomic environment would be negligible, this topic is dismissed.
label: BODY

text: Prime and Unique Farmlands
label: BODY

text: In August 1980, the Council on Environmental Quality (CEQ) directed that federal agencies
label: BODY

text: must assess the effects of their actions on farmland soils classified by the U.S. Department of
label: BODY

text: Agriculture's Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) as prime or unique. Prime or
label: BODY

text: unique farmland is defined as soil that particularly produces general crops such as common
label: BODY

text: foods, forage, fiber, and oil seed; unique farmland produces specialty crops such as fruits,
label: BODY

text: vegetables, and nuts. There are 68 acres of prime and unique agricultural lands in the Fruita
label: BODY

text: Valley in the park. These lands are composed of orchards, pastures, and open fields, which are
label: BODY

text: part of a National Register-listed cultural landscape. As such, these lands are protected under
label: BODY

text: the National Historic Preservation Act, which limits development and use of the district. Neither
label: BODY

text: alternative will affect the manner in which these lands are managed. Specifically, the portion of
label: BODY

text: the project that passes through the Fruita Rural Historic District orchards will not affect fruit trees
label: BODY

text: Resurface the 8-Mile Scenic Drive Road Environmental Assessment
label: BODY

text: Capitol Reef National Park
label: BODY

text: or orchard operation. Because there would be no effects on prime and unique farmlands, this
label: BODY

text: topic is dismissed from further analysis in this document.

text: Indian Trust Resources
label: BODY

text: Secretarial Order 3175 requires that any anticipated impacts to Indian trust resources from a
label: BODY

text: proposed project or action by the Department of Interior agencies be explicitly addressed in
label: BODY

text: environmental documents. The federal Indian trust responsibility is a legally enforceable
label: BODY

text: fiduciary obligation on the part of the United States to protect tribal lands, assets, resources,
label: BODY

text: and treaty rights, and it represents a duty to carry out the mandates of federal law with respect
label: BODY

text: to Native American and Alaska Native tribes.
label: BODY

text: There are no Indian trust resources at Capitol Reef National Park. The lands comprising the
label: BODY

text: park are not held in trust by the Secretary of the Interior for the benefit of Indians due to their
label: BODY

text: status as Indians. Because there are no Indian trust resources, this topic is dismissed from
label: BODY

text: further analysis in this document.
label: BODY

text: Environmental Justice
label: BODY

text: Executive Order 12898 General Actions to Address Environmental Justice in Minority
label: BODY

text: Populations and Low-Income Populations requires all federal agencies to incorporate
label: BODY

text: environmental justice into their missions by identifying and addressing disproportionately high
label: BODY

text: and adverse human health or environmental effects of their programs and policies on minorities
label: BODY

text: and low-income populations and communities. Because the new administration facility would be
label: BODY

text: available for use by all park staff regardless of race or income, and the construction workforces
label: BODY

text: would not be hired based on their race or income, the proposed action would not have
label: BODY

text: disproportionate health or environmental effects on minorities or low income populations or
label: BODY

text: communities. Because there would be no disproportionate effects, this topic is dismissed from
label: BODY

text: further analysis in this document.
label: BODY

text: Climate Change and Sustainability
label: BODY

text: Although climatologists are unsure about the long-term results of global climate change, it is
label: BODY

text: clear that the planet is experiencing a warming trend that affects ocean currents, sea levels,
label: BODY

text: polar sea ice, and global weather patterns. Although these changes will likely affect winter
label: BODY

text: precipitation patterns and amounts in the parks, it would be speculative to predict localized
label: BODY

text: changes in temperature, precipitation, or other weather changes, in part because there are
label: BODY

text: many variables that are not fully understood and there may be variables not currently defined.
label: BODY

text: Therefore, the analyses in this document are based on past and current weather patterns, and
label: BODY

text: the effects of future climate changes are not discussed further.
label: BODY

text: During October 2009, an interdisciplinary team of National Park Service and Federal Highway
label: BODY

text: Administration employees met for the purpose of discussing the scope of the proposed project
label: BODY

text: and developing project alternatives. This meeting resulted in the definition of project objectives
label: BODY

text: as described in the Purpose and Need, and a list of alternatives that could potentially meet
label: BODY

text: these objectives. An action alternative and the no-action alternative were originally identified for
label: BODY

text: this project. A number of options that were considered for the action alternative were dismissed
label: BODY

text: from further consideration for various reasons, as described later in this chapter. One action
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: the end of this chapter.

text: Alternatives Carried Forward
label: BODY

text: Alternative A – No-Action
label: BODY

text: The no-action alternative consists of the park’s ongoing routine of maintenance and repairs. It
label: BODY

text: does not imply or direct discontinuing day-to-day maintenance and repairs. The park would
label: BODY

text: continue to clear culverts, stabilize slopes, patch potholes, and complete other isolated repairs
label: BODY

text: as the need arises. The road would continue to deteriorate, and repair costs would continue to
label: BODY

text: escalate. Temporary road closures for repairs would become more frequent. Should the no-
label: BODY

text: action alternative be selected, the NPS would respond to future needs and conditions without
label: BODY

text: major actions or changes in the present course.
label: BODY

text: Alternative B – Rehabilitate and Resurface the Scenic Drive (Preferred Alternative)
label: BODY

text: The Scenic Drive would be rehabilitated and repaved throughout its 8-mile length between SR-
label: BODY

text: 24 and the Capitol Gorge parking area. The existing roadway width would be maintained, but
label: BODY

text: the pavement would be widened at “S-shaped” curves to help prevent vehicles from off-tracking
label: BODY

text: onto the shoulders. The roadway would also be widened at its southern end to provide a
label: BODY

text: consistent width. The subgrade throughout the length of the Scenic Drive would be excavated
label: BODY

text: as needed in spot locations, and replaced with appropriate fill material. From milepost (MP)
label: BODY

text: 0.00, the intersection with SR-24, to the park fee station at MP 1.70, the existing pavement on
label: BODY

text: the Scenic Drive would be pulverized and the roadway would be paved with asphalt concrete.
label: BODY

text: Between the fee station and the Capitol Gorge parking area the existing chip-seal pavement
label: BODY

text: would be pulverized, and the roadway would be paved with a double chip-seal overlay. Painted
label: BODY

text: centerline striping would be applied from the picnic area and campground in the Fruita Historic
label: BODY

text: District to the intersection with SR-24. Centerline striping may also be applied at some of the
label: BODY

text: sharpest curves, to enhance safety. Rumble strips would be installed at the beginning of the 15-
label: BODY

text: mile-per-hour speed zone. Minor improvements would be made to the Fruita Campground
label: BODY

text: entrance to provide additional width for turning movements into and out of the campground.
label: BODY

text: Paved asphalt aprons would be developed and extended into the entrances of Grand Wash and
label: BODY

text: the Pleasant Creek Road.
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: include reconstructing and paving the ditch with a consistent cross section and slope to more
label: BODY

text: easily accommodate mechanical maintenance, or retaining the current native soil ditch while

text: implementing a schedule of more frequent maintenance. The native soil ditch would be

text: Staging Areas
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Pendleton Field and the boneyard is by a gravel road immediately south of the Fee Station. Cal
label: BODY

text: Pendleton Field is adjacent to the Scenic Drive while the boneyard is approximately one-half
label: BODY

text: mile west. Materials for park use are commonly stored at the boneyard now and it has been
label: BODY

text: disturbed by park vehicles. It has been used as a construction staging area in the past. Cal
label: BODY

text: Pendleton Field is a pasture area but is not currently being used in any capacity by the park.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Mitigation Measures
label: BODY

text: The following mitigation measures were developed to minimize the degree and/or severity of
label: BODY

text: adverse effects and would be implemented during construction of the action alternative, as
label: BODY

text: needed:
label: BODY

text: To minimize the amount of ground disturbance, staging and stockpiling areas would be in
label: BODY

text: previously disturbed sites, away from visitor use areas to the extent possible. All staging and
label: BODY

text: stockpiling areas would be returned to pre-construction conditions following construction.
label: BODY

text: Fugitive dust generated by construction would be controlled by spraying water on the
label: BODY

text: construction site, if necessary.
label: BODY

text: Contractors would be required to properly maintain construction equipment (i.e., mufflers
label: BODY

text: and brakes) to minimize noise. Construction equipment would not be permitted to idle for
label: BODY

text: long periods of time.
label: BODY

text: To minimize possible petrochemical leaks from construction equipment, the contractor would
label: BODY

text: regularly monitor and check construction equipment to identify and repair any leaks.
label: BODY

text: All tools, equipment, barricades, signs, surplus materials, and rubbish would be removed
label: BODY

text: upon project completion.
label: BODY

text: Revegetation efforts would strive to reconstruct the natural spacing, abundance, and
label: BODY

text: diversity of native plant species using native species. A revegetation plan approved by NPS
label: BODY

text: would be developed for disturbances in the project area.
label: BODY

text: All disturbed areas would be restored as much as is feasible to pre-construction conditions
label: BODY

text: shortly after construction activities were completed. Weed control methods would be
label: BODY

text: implemented to minimize the introduction of noxious weeds. Remedial actions would include
label: BODY

text: installation of erosion-control structures, reseeding, topsoil placement, and/or replanting the
label: BODY

text: area, and controlling non-native plant species with herbicide.
label: BODY

text: Because disturbed soils would be susceptible to erosion, until the soil was stable and
label: BODY

text: vegetation was established, standard erosion control measures would be used to minimize
label: BODY

text: any potential soil erosion and prevent sediment from reaching streams.
label: BODY

text: Treatment of non-native vegetation would be completed in accordance with NPS–13,
label: BODY

text: Integrated Pest Management Guidelines. Monitoring and follow-up treatment of exotic
label: BODY

text: vegetation would occur after project activities are completed.
label: BODY

text: To prevent the introduction of, and minimize the spread of, nonnative vegetation and
label: BODY

text: noxious weeds, the following measures would be implemented during construction:
label: BODY

text: o Soil disturbance would be minimized.
label: BODY

text: o To avoid introduction of non-native/noxious plant species, no hay bales would be
label: BODY

text: used for temporary erosion control or during revegetation.
label: BODY

text: o All construction equipment would be pressure washed and/or steam cleaned before
label: BODY

text: entering the park to ensure that all equipment is weed-free.
label: BODY

text: Resurface the 8-Mile Scenic Drive Road Environmental Assessment
label: BODY

text: Capitol Reef National Park
label: BODY

text: o All haul trucks bringing fill materials from outside the park would be covered to
label: BODY

text: prevent seed transport.
label: BODY

text: o Vehicle and equipment parking would be limited to within construction limits or
label: BODY

text: approved staging areas.
label: BODY

text: o Staging areas outside the park would be surveyed for noxious weeds and treated
label: BODY

text: appropriately prior to use.
label: BODY

text: o All fill, rock, and additional topsoil would be obtained from stockpiles from previous
label: BODY

text: projects or excess material from this project, if possible; and if not possible, then
label: BODY

text: weed-free fill, rock, or additional topsoil would be obtained from sources outside the

text: park. NPS personnel would certify that the source is weed-free.

text: Erosion control BMPs for drainage and sediment control, as identified and used by the
label: BODY

text: FHWA and NPS, would be implemented to prevent or reduce nonpoint source pollution and
label: BODY

text: minimize soil loss and sedimentation in drainage areas. These practices may include, but
label: BODY

text: would not be limited to, silt fencing, filter fabric, temporary sediment ponds, check dams of
label: BODY

text: pea gravel-filled burlap bags or other material, and/or immediate mulching of exposed areas

text: to minimize sedimentation and turbidity impacts as a result of construction activities. The

label: BODY

text: Accumulated sediments would be removed when the fabric was estimated to be
label: BODY

text: approximately 75% full. Silt removal would be accomplished in such a way as to avoid
label: BODY

text: introducing sediments into any flowing water bodies.
label: BODY

text: Regular site inspections would be conducted to ensure that erosion control measures were
label: BODY

text: properly installed and functioning effectively.

text: The operation of ground-disturbing equipment would be temporarily suspended during large

text: streams.

text: Options were considered for rehabilitating a ditch at approximately milepost 1.25. The existing
label: BODY

text: ditch does not effectively intercept and convey storm flows from the adjacent steep slopes.
label: BODY

text: Sediment-laden stormwaters sometimes overflow the ditch, damaging the roadway and flowing
label: BODY

text: into the nearby historic Gifford barn. The following options for preventing those flows were
label: BODY

text: considered, but were dismissed.
label: BODY

text: 1. Install a relief culvert halfway down the existing ditch. Although a relief culvert would
label: BODY

text: convey a portion of the water under the road, it is likely that the culvert would plug with
label: BODY

text: sediment and become inoperative.
label: BODY

text: 2. Raise the roadway profile . It was determined that raising the roadway profile would not
label: BODY

text: be feasible, because the increased cost would not provide a correspondingly higher level
label: BODY

text: of protection for the roadway or the barn. The option that was selected as part of the
label: BODY

text: preferred alternative (a concrete-lined ditch) would provide equivalent protection for the
label: BODY

text: roadway and the barn and would cost appreciably less.
label: BODY

text: The option of painting white edge striping (sometimes referred to as a fog line) along the
label: BODY

text: outside edge of each travel lane was considered as roadway striping option, but that option
label: BODY

text: was dismissed. Park Service and FHWA interdisciplinary team members felt that such
label: BODY

text: striping could induce vehicle operators to drive closer to the centerline, actually decreasing
label: BODY

text: safety.

text: Identification of the Environmentally Preferred Alternative
label: BODY

text: The environmentally preferred alternative is determined by applying the criteria suggested in the
label: BODY

text: National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (NEPA), which guides the Council on Environmental
label: BODY

text: Quality (CEQ). The CEQ provides direction that “[t]he environmentally preferable alternative is
label: BODY

text: the alternative that would promote the national environmental policy as expressed as goals in
label: BODY

text: NEPA’s §101:
label: BODY

text: 1. fulfill the responsibilities of each generation as trustee of the environment for succeeding
label: BODY

text: generations;
label: BODY

text: 2. assure for all generations safe, healthful, productive, and esthetically and culturally
label: BODY

text: pleasing surroundings;
label: BODY

text: 3. attain the widest range of beneficial uses of the environment without degradation, risk of
label: BODY

text: health or safety, or other undesirable and unintended consequences;
label: BODY

text: 4. preserve important historic, cultural and natural aspects of our national heritage and
label: BODY

text: maintain, wherever possible, an environment that supports diversity and variety of
label: BODY

text: individual choice;
label: BODY

text: 5. achieve a balance between population and resource use that will permit high standards
label: BODY

text: of living and a wide sharing of life’s amenities; and
label: BODY

text: 6. enhance the quality of renewable resources and approach the maximum attainable
label: BODY

text: recycling of depletable resources.
label: BODY

text: While the no action alternative (alternative A) would preserve existing conditions, it would
label: BODY

text: not be considered the environmentally preferred alternative because not rehabilitating the
label: BODY

text: Resurface the 8-Mile Scenic Drive Road Environmental Assessment
label: BODY

text: Capitol Reef National Park
label: BODY

text: Scenic Drive, repairing damaged road and drainage problems, and implementing other
label: BODY

text: improvements would not meet environmental goals in the same manner as the preferred
label: BODY

text: alternative. Alternative A is not the environmentally preferred alternative for the following
label: BODY

text: reasons: 1. not rehabilitating the Scenic Drive would not meet the stewardship responsibility
label: BODY

text: for protecting park resources (goal 1, as expressed in NEPA’s §101); 2. it would not improve
label: BODY

text: road safety or protection of environmental and cultural resources (goals 2, 3, and 4);
label: BODY

text: 3. damaged road sections would continue to deteriorate and result in increased
label: BODY

text: maintenance costs (and would not fully meet goal 3); and 4. there is a higher likelihood of
label: BODY

text: road failure, which would result in road closure, making it more difficult for visitors and staff
label: BODY

text: to access park facilities (goal 5). Thus, alternative A does not fully meet the provisions of
label: BODY

text: NEPA §101 goals 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5.

text: The NPS determined that the environmentally preferred alternative is the preferred
label: BODY

text: alternative (alternative B) because it surpasses alternative A in realizing the full range of

text: the widest range of beneficial uses without degradation, and would reduce risks to health
label: BODY

text: and safety because it would provide sustainable vehicular access to the facilities and
label: BODY

text: trailheads along the Scenic Drive. Implementing alternative B would best preserve the

text: natural and cultural features along the road because it implements structural improvements
label: BODY

text: while providing long-term protection of environmental and cultural resources (goals 1 and 4).

text: Detailed information on the natural, cultural, and human resources at Capitol Reef National Park
label: BODY

text: may be found in the final general management plan (NPS, 2001). A summary of the resources
