text: Location and General Description of the Park
label: BODY

text: Capitol Reef National Park is located in south-central Utah approximately 225 miles south of
label: BODY

text: Salt Lake City. The entrance to the park is on Utah State Road 24 between the towns of Torrey
label: BODY

text: and Hanksville. The park was established by Congress as a national monument on August 2,
label: BODY

text: 1937, to preserve the geologic resources of the area. It was redesignated a national park in
label: BODY

text: 1971 and increased six times it original size. The park protects Cathedral Valley, ancient sand
label: BODY

text: dunes and other objects of scientific interest, and the majority of the Waterpocket Fold. The
label: BODY

text: Waterpocket Fold is the largest wrinkle in the earth’s crust (monocline) in North America.
label: BODY

text: Approximately 617,208 recreational visitors came to Capitol Reef National Park in 2009. In the
label: BODY

text: past 30 years annual visitation has fluctuated between a low of 516,000 in 2002 to a high of
label: BODY

text: The primary mode of transportation to the park is the private automobile. The park's main
label: BODY

text: driving tours include the Scenic Drive and two mainly unpaved, loop tours through the park's
label: BODY

text: Cathedral and Waterpocket Districts. The park offers a brochure for a self-guided tour of the
label: BODY

text: Scenic Drive with eleven stops that highlight the geologic and historical features of interest in
label: BODY

text: the park.
label: BODY

text: Ninety-one percent of park visits include the Scenic Drive. Approximately 70,000 vehicles a year
label: BODY

text: travel the road, based on a traffic study completed in 2004. The average number of vehicles per
label: BODY

text: day traveling along the Scenic Drive is over 200, with the peak in May of over 400 vehicles per
label: BODY

text: day.
label: BODY

text: Visitor services include a picnic area, three campgrounds and a visitor center. The Fruita
label: BODY

text: Campground is developed, and the Cathedral and Cedar Mesa campgrounds are primitive.
label: BODY

text: Backcountry camping is available by permit. The most common visitor activities are viewing
label: BODY

text: scenery (93%), followed by photography/painting/drawing (78%) and hiking (70%) (Capitol Reef
label: BODY

text: National Park Visitor Study, 2008). There are fifteen hiking trails in the park, ranging in degree
label: BODY

text: of difficulty from easy to strenuous. Additional recreational opportunities available at the park
label: BODY

text: include climbing, biking, horseback riding and camping. Other popular activities consist of
label: BODY

text: visiting the historic buildings and fruit picking in the orchards of the Fruita Historic District, a
label: BODY

text: Mormon pioneer settlement. Capitol Reef has the largest historic orchards in the National Park
label: BODY

text: System, with approximately 2,600 fruit and nut trees.
label: BODY

text: Cultural Landscapes
label: BODY

text: The Scenic Drive is a narrow, winding historic road that was originally built in 1883 to link the
label: BODY

text: new settlement of Junction (later, Fruita) to other nearby settlements. The road followed traces
label: BODY

text: of an ancient route used by Native Americans along the western edge of the Waterpocket Fold.
label: BODY

text: Portions of the original route have also been known by other names, including the Blue Dugway,
label: BODY

text: Capitol Gorge Highway, Reef Road, Monument Road, and old Utah State Route 24. A two-mile
label: BODY

text: section of the road is a contributing landscape feature of the Fruita Rural Historic District. The
label: BODY

text: NPS also considers the Scenic Drive/Capitol Gorge as a separate component landscape within
label: BODY

text: the park that is potentially eligible for listing in the National Register of Historic Places.
label: BODY

text: Resurface the 8-Mile Scenic Drive Road Environmental Assessment
label: BODY

text: Capitol Reef National Park
label: BODY

text: The original route of the Scenic Drive was not highly engineered, and remained little more than
label: BODY

text: a simple wagon road until the mid-twentieth century. Between 1938 and1942, workers from a
label: BODY

text: Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) sub-camp established in the park completed some
label: BODY

text: improvements to the Scenic Drive. A section of the road southeast of the Fremont River Bridge
label: BODY

text: was stabilized. Improvements were also completed at the Danish Hill area south of Fruita. Some
label: BODY

text: portions of the route were widened from 11 feet to18 feet, and cut slope flattening to improve
label: BODY

text: sight distance was also completed.
label: BODY

text: It is unclear which drainage features date to the CCC era, and which were constructed earlier
label: BODY

text: and simply repaired or rebuilt between 1938 and 1942. The Scenic Drive currently has 64
label: BODY

text: culverts and 22 low water crossings. An inventory of culverts completed by park staff in 2009
label: BODY

text: identified six that are known or are likely to have been constructed by the CCC, in addition to
label: BODY

text: another 31 possible CCC-era drainage features. Historical records also indicate that four
label: BODY

text: hundred feet of rock wall was constructed during this period to improve the grade and drainage,
label: BODY

text: and stone check dams were placed in eroding ditches.
label: BODY

text: By the late 1950s, when the NPS Mission 66 development period was well underway, the park
label: BODY

text: initiated planning for the rerouting of State Highway 24. In 1962 the new highway was realigned
label: BODY

text: to run east-west along the Fremont River, with portions following the general alignment of the
label: BODY

text: historic route. The Old State Route 24 road from Fruita to Capitol Gorge was renamed the
label: BODY

text: Scenic Drive, and the section that extended northeast through the gorge was closed. Minor
label: BODY

text: alignments were also completed during this period. Park records note the addition of twelve new
label: BODY

text: culverts to address drainage problems.
label: BODY

text: Over the years, the Scenic Drive was widened to approximately 20 feet, although some areas
label: BODY

text: are narrower. The Fremont Bridge was replaced in 1985 and the section of road between Fruita
label: BODY

text: and Capitol Gorge, formerly gravel, was chip-sealed in 1988. Gabion walls, at least four low
label: BODY

text: water crossings, and pullouts were also constructed. However, despite these alterations, the
label: BODY

text: Scenic Drive retains its rustic character.
label: BODY

text: Soundscape
label: BODY

text: Generally, ambient sound levels in the vicinity of the proposed project are low and are
label: BODY

text: dominated by natural sounds. In the project area natural sounds include the sounds of wind,
label: BODY

text: running water, birds, and occasionally other animal sounds.
label: BODY

text: Vehicle traffic is the main source of human-caused noise in the project area. Although roadway
label: BODY

text: speeds are low, visitor traffic intermittently increases noise levels, particularly during the
label: BODY

text: summer months when traffic levels are higher. Noise is also produced during road maintenance
label: BODY

text: activities. Summer is the busiest season for road maintenance. Because of weather limitations,
label: BODY

text: part of the construction work for the proposed project would occur during the summer.
label: BODY

text: Actual ambient sound levels along the Scenic Drive are not known, but as a frame of reference,
label: BODY

text: the sound level on a totally quiet night in a desert would be around 30 decibels (dBA), while
label: BODY

text: sound levels from light traffic on paved roads range from 45 to 50 dBA at a distance of 100 feet
label: BODY

text: from the roadway.
label: BODY

text: Geology and Soils
label: BODY

text: The Scenic Drive follows the western face of the Waterpocket Fold. The geology in the area
label: BODY

text: dates from the Permian (as old as 270 million years) to the Cretaceous (around 80 million years
label: BODY

text: old). The Waterpocket Fold has tilted the geologic strata down to the east. The older rocks are
label: BODY

text: found in the western part of the park, and the younger rocks are found near the east boundary.
label: BODY

text: The geology of the area includes the reddish-brown mudstones, siltstones, claystones, and fine

text: grained sandstones of the Moenkopi Formation and the grayer band of Chinle shale (originally
label: BODY

text: deposited as volcanic ash), to the distinctive red, white, and reddish-brown colors and various
label: BODY

text: shapes assumed by the sandstones of the Wingate, Navajo, and Kayenta formations.
label: BODY

text: Soils in the area of the proposed project are typically very loose, fine-grained, poorly graded
label: BODY

text: silty sand, with some gravel and boulders. The soils are derived from the sandstones and
label: BODY

text: shales that predominate the geology of the park. Such soils are easily infiltrated and eroded by
label: BODY

text: water, and can also become hydro-compacted.
label: BODY

text: Heavier soils, such as silty clay loams, can be found at the base of shale slopes and hills
label: BODY

text: throughout the project area. Soils along the Fremont River floodplain are derived from alluvium
label: BODY

text: deposited by the river. In the Fruita area, silty clay loam floodplain soils were successfully
label: BODY

text: farmed, producing alfalfa, sorghum, vegetables, and a variety of fruit orchards. The NPS has
label: BODY

text: continued that history of cultivation within the park.
label: BODY

text: Health and Safety
label: BODY

text: The rustic characteristics of the Scenic Drive make it suited for low volume traffic flow with slow
label: BODY

text: travel speeds. This works well for visitors using the road to access park facilities, which include
label: BODY

text: the visitor center, a campground, trailheads, and the Fruita Historic District with its homestead
label: BODY

text: buildings and orchards. It is a park road only, and is not an element of the local or county traffic
label: BODY

text: patterns. However, the volume and types of public use have increased since the establishment
label: BODY

text: of the park. The Scenic Drive pre-dates the establishment of the park and was not constructed
label: BODY

text: to currently accepted standards for the volume and types of public use the road now receives.
label: BODY

text: Health and safety concerns include the narrow road width, tight curves, debris such as rocks in
label: BODY

text: the roadway, the possibility of flash flooding in the washes crossed by the road, and seasonal
label: BODY

text: heat and cold.
label: BODY

text: Collisions between vehicles are not frequent. Park records report two vehicle collisions on the
label: BODY

text: Scenic Drive from 1990 through 1993, and two vehicle collisions from 2005 through 2008. The
label: BODY

text: causes of the accidents were reported as inattention and speeding, and some were identified as
label: BODY

text: sideswipe collisions on S-shaped curves. Sliding off the road and striking debris in the road are
label: BODY

text: also identified as causes for accidents on the Scenic Drive.
label: BODY

text: Restroom facilities and potable water are located at the visitor center and the headquarters area
label: BODY

text: (at the intersection of Highway 24 and the Scenic Drive) and in Fruita Campground. The
label: BODY

text: campground is developed  with 71 recreational vehicle (RV) and/or tent sites, each with a picnic
label: BODY

text: table and grill but no individual water, sewage, or electrical hook-ups. An RV dump station is
label: BODY

text: open during the summer. The campground restrooms are heated and feature potable running
label: BODY

text: water and flush toilets, but not showers. There are toilet facilities at the southern end of the
label: BODY

text: Scenic drive where it intersects unpaved spur roads into Grand Wash and Capitol Gorge.
label: BODY

text: The park coordinates law enforcement and related activities with neighboring counties. Most
label: BODY

text: emergency services, such as search and rescue and initial-response emergency medical
label: BODY

text: services for incidents within the park, are provided by park staff. Emergency medical response
label: BODY

text: staff have offices in the park headquarters. A medical clinic is located in Bicknell, 19 miles west
label: BODY

text: of the park on Utah Highway 24. The closest hospital is located in Richfield, 75 miles west of the
label: BODY

text: park. There is limited cell phone service in most areas of the park, but park radios work well
label: BODY

text: along the Scenic Drive corridor.
label: BODY

text: Fire personnel from the park and from other agencies work together to accomplish each
label: BODY

text: agency’s fire management goals. Neighboring agencies will provide assistance with emergency
label: BODY

text: fire suppression when requested, in accordance with the Annual Operating Plan for Fire
label: BODY

text: Resurface the 8-Mile Scenic Drive Road Environmental Assessment
label: BODY

text: Capitol Reef National Park
label: BODY

text: Management between the U.S. Forest Service, the Bureau of Land Management, National Park
label: BODY

text: Service, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Bureau of Indian Affairs, and the State of Utah.
label: BODY

text: Visitor Use and Experience
label: BODY

text: About 665,000 people visited the park in 2009. The average length of stay for visitor groups who
label: BODY

text: spend less than 24 hours in the park is about 6 hours. Approximately 92% stop at the visitor
label: BODY

text: center and 91% travel the Scenic Drive. The primary visitor activities are driving the Scenic
label: BODY

text: Drive, viewing the scenery, and visiting the Fruita Historic District. Besides the paved Scenic
label: BODY

text: Drive, there are unpaved loop tours through the Cathedral and Waterpocket Districts of the
label: BODY

text: park.
label: BODY

text: Hiking is a popular visitor activity. In the Fruita area, there are 15 day-hiking trails with trailheads
label: BODY

text: located along Utah Highway 24 and the Scenic Drive. There are also numerous hiking options
label: BODY

text: for serious backpackers and those who enjoy exploring remote areas.
label: BODY

text: Horse and pack animal use is also permitted in the park along several park roads and trails.
label: BODY

text: There are limited overnight facilities for stock users, and backcountry use permits are available
label: BODY

text: for backcountry camping with stock.
label: BODY

text: The park offers camping in the developed Fruita campground and the nearby group
label: BODY

text: campground. There are two primitive campgrounds in more remote parts of the park, and
label: BODY

text: backcountry camping is also permitted.
label: BODY

text: Rock climbing is becoming increasingly popular in the park, as in Utah’s canyon country in
label: BODY

text: general. Bicycling is allowed, though cyclists must stay on designated roads at all times.
label: BODY

text: Cyclists may not travel off road, in washes, on closed roads, on hiking trails, or backcountry
label: BODY

text: routes.
label: BODY

text: From May to September, the park offers a variety of ranger-guided programs at no charge.
label: BODY

text: These include guided walks, talks, and evening programs at the campground amphitheater.
label: BODY

text: Park Operations and Management
label: BODY

text: The park has approximately 24 permanent employees, and additional seasonal employees in
label: BODY

text: the summer months. Interns and volunteers augment the paid staff. Personnel resources are
label: BODY

text: distributed among the superintendent’s office, administration, interpretation, maintenance,
label: BODY

text: resource management and science, and visitor and resource protection functions.
label: BODY

text: The park has a visitor center, an administrative headquarters complex, a maintenance building,
label: BODY

text: a service yard, and a 15-unit residential area. The Fruita Rural Historic District within the park
label: BODY

text: includes a 3,000-tree orchard complex. Many historic buildings within the park, including wood
label: BODY

text: frame homes and barns, are used for staff and/or interpretive purposes, The park has
label: BODY

text: equipment such as trucks, trailers, and construction equipment to support park operations.
label: BODY

text: The 71-site Fruita Campground is the only developed campground in the park, located south of
label: BODY

text: the visitor center in the Fruita Historic District. A group campground, available by reservation for
label: BODY

text: as many as 40 people, is located near the Fruita Campground. Two no-fee primitive
label: BODY

text: campgrounds in more remote parts of the park have pit toilets and picnic tables, but no water.
label: BODY

text: The only paved roads within the park are State Road 24 and the Scenic Drive. Unpaved roads
label: BODY

text: include the Capitol Gorge and Grand Wash spur roads, South Draw Road, Hartnet Road,
label: BODY

text: Caineville Wash Road, Burr Trail Road, and Notom-Bullfrog Road.
label: BODY

text: For management purposes the park is divided into six types of zones: primitive, semi-primitive,
label: BODY

text: threshold, rural developed, utility corridor, and road corridors.
label: BODY

text: Resurface the 8-Mile Scenic Drive Road Environmental Assessment
label: BODY

text: Capitol Reef National Park
label: BODY

text: In the primitive zone, management strategies focus on wilderness qualities, allowing natural
label: BODY

text: processes and undeveloped native conditions to continue with minimal human interference.
label: BODY

text: Native species are maintained or re-established, and sensitive species are protected or
label: BODY

text: augmented. Attempts are made to eliminate non-native species. Some grazing and related
label: BODY

text: development is allowed. The primitive zone can be approached via a limited number of roads,
label: BODY

text: primarily four-wheel drive roads and high clearance, two-wheel drive dirt roads. Travel through
label: BODY

text: this zone requires cross-country hiking or horseback riding on unimproved trails and routes.
label: BODY

text: The semi-primitive zone is similar in nature to the primitive zone, except that evidence of human
label: BODY

text: activity is more pronounced. Road corridors are more abundant, and human access is easier.
label: BODY

text: Grazing and related development is allowed. Maintenance activities should be rare, solely for
label: BODY

text: protecting resources and restoring areas disturbed by human activities. The semi-primitive zone
label: BODY

text: can be accessed by a number of roads, primarily two-wheel drive dirt roads. Travel through this
label: BODY

text: zone requires cross-country hiking or horseback riding on unimproved trails and routes.
label: BODY

text: The threshold zone accommodates more varied human activities. Interpretation is provided
label: BODY

text: along maintained hiking trails. A moderate degree of resource management is required. Natural
label: BODY

text: processes are perpetuated and natural conditions are maintained as much as possible, but
label: BODY

text: some human alterations and intrusions are evident. Access is on paved or two-wheel drive, low-
label: BODY

text: clearance, all-weather roads. Access to the zone interior is along a variety of trails and routes
label: BODY

text: that connect various destination points.
label: BODY

text: The rural developed zone encompasses the park headquarters, the Fruita campground, and the
label: BODY

text: Sleeping Rainbow Ranch developed areas. The zone is moderately developed and it sustains
label: BODY

text: the highest level of visitor use. It includes the Fruita Rural Historic District. Also located in the
label: BODY

text: zone are the park visitor center, maintenance facilities, and employee housing. Vehicle access
label: BODY

text: to and throughout the zone is by paved and unpaved roads suitable for most vehicles.
label: BODY

text: Pedestrian access is provided by maintained trails that allow visitors to explore natural and
label: BODY

text: cultural environments. Some trail sections are wheelchair-accessible.
label: BODY

text: The utility corridor zone contains the permanent physical plant and infrastructure developments
label: BODY

text: relating to utilities delivery, such as electricity, irrigation water, and telephone service. Corridor
label: BODY

text: widths vary according to right-of-way agreements or special use permits. Visitors can expect to
label: BODY

text: encounter power lines, water developments, underground telephone lines, utility junction boxes,
label: BODY

text: and other such developments. The natural character of the land is preserved, while
label: BODY

text: accommodating utility development and maintenance. Visitor access to the zone varies
label: BODY

text: considerably, depending on the terrain.
label: BODY

text: Road corridor zones identify all primary, secondary, and four-wheel drive vehicle routes
label: BODY

text: established within the park. Bicycles and licensed vehicles manufactured for highway use may
label: BODY

text: travel on park roads. Visitors can expect a variety of road conditions, ranging from a paved,
label: BODY

text: well-maintained, state highway to minimally maintained, high clearance, variable-width dirt
label: BODY

text: roads.
label: BODY

text: The Scenic Drive is one of the road corridors in the park. Users can expect a well-maintained,
label: BODY

text: hard-surfaced road meandering through the rural cultural landscape and through the threshold
label: BODY

text: zone, with turnouts, trailhead parking areas, interpretive signs, wayside exhibits, and picnic
label: BODY

text: sites. Routine maintenance activities include filling potholes and depressions, repairing eroded
label: BODY

text: shoulders, removing debris from roadway drains, and chip-sealing the roadway as needed.
label: BODY

text: ENVIRONMENTAL CONSEQUENCES
label: H1

text: Methodology
label: BODY

text: This chapter analyzes the potential environmental consequences, or impacts, that would occur
label: BODY

text: as a result of implementing the proposed project. Topics analyzed in this chapter include
label: BODY

text: cultural landscapes, soundscape, geology and soils, visitor use and experience, and park
label: BODY

text: operations. Direct, indirect, and cumulative effects are analyzed for each resource topic carried
label: BODY

text: forward. Natural and cultural resource topics are also analyzed for impairment. Potential
label: BODY

text: impacts are described in terms of type, context, duration, and intensity. General definitions are
label: BODY

text: defined as follows, while more specific impact thresholds are given for each resource at the
label: BODY

text: beginning of each resource section.
label: BODY

text: • Type describes the classification of the impact as either beneficial or adverse, direct or
label: BODY

text: indirect:
label: BODY

text: - Beneficial: A positive change in the condition or appearance of the resource or a change
label: BODY

text: that moves the resource toward a desired condition.
label: BODY

text: - Adverse: A change that moves the resource away from a desired condition or detracts
label: BODY

text: from its appearance or condition.
label: BODY

text: - Direct: An effect that is caused by an action and occurs in the same time and place.
label: BODY

text: - Indirect: An effect that is caused by an action but is later in time or farther removed in
label: BODY

text: distance, but is still reasonably foreseeable.
label: BODY

text: • Context describes the area or location in which the impact will occur. Are the effects site-
label: BODY

text: specific, local, regional, or even broader?
label: BODY

text: • Duration describes the length of time an effect will occur, either short-term or long-term:
label: BODY

text: - Short-term impacts generally last only during construction, and the resources resume
label: BODY

text: their pre-construction conditions following construction.
label: BODY

text: - Long-term impacts last beyond the construction period, and the resources may not
label: BODY

text: resume their pre-construction conditions for a longer period of time following construction.
label: BODY

text: • Intensity describes the degree, level, or strength of an impact. For this analysis, intensity has
label: BODY

text: been categorized into negligible, minor, moderate, and major. Because definitions of intensity
label: BODY

text: vary by resource topic, intensity definitions are provided separately for each impact topic
label: BODY

text: analyzed in this environmental assessment.
label: BODY

text: Note: NPS policy requires that direct and indirect impacts be “considered.” However,
label: BODY

text: directness is not to be specifically labeled or identified as “direct/indirect” in any of the impact
label: BODY

text: topics in the environmental consequences chapter.
label: BODY

text: Cumulative Effects
label: BODY

text: The Council on Environmental Quality (CEQ) regulations, which implement the National
label: BODY

text: Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (42 USC 4321 et seq.), require assessment of cumulative
label: BODY

text: impacts in the decision-making process for federal projects. Cumulative impacts are defined as
label: BODY

text: "the impact on the environment which results from the incremental impact of the action when
label: BODY

text: added to other past, present, and reasonably foreseeable future actions regardless of what
label: BODY

text: agency (federal or non-federal) or person undertakes such other actions" (40 CFR 1508.7).
label: BODY

text: Cumulative impacts are considered for both the no-action and preferred alternative.
label: BODY

text: Resurface the 8-Mile Scenic Drive Road Environmental Assessment
label: BODY

text: Capitol Reef National Park
label: BODY

text: Cumulative impacts were determined by combining the impacts of the preferred alternative with
label: BODY

text: other past, present, and reasonably foreseeable future actions. Therefore, it was necessary to
label: BODY

text: identify projects at Capitol Reef National Park and, if applicable, the surrounding region. The
label: BODY

text: following projects were identified for the purpose of conducting the cumulative effects analysis,
label: BODY

text: listed from past to future:
label: BODY

text: Erosion control/bank stabilization measures along State Route 24: The NPS and the Utah
label: BODY

text: Department of Transportation installed erosion control/bank stabilization measures along State
label: BODY

text: Route 24 within Capitol Reef National Park.
label: BODY

text: Development of the Sleeping Rainbow Ranch as a research facility: The project included
label: BODY

text: demolishing and replacing existing buildings and utilities on a mesa top approximately two miles
label: BODY

text: southwest of the Capitol Gorge parking area. Additional facilities were constructed for use as a
label: BODY

text: year-round educational site.
label: BODY

text: Replace administration trailer with permanent building:  The park is in the process of replacing
label: BODY

text: the existing administration offices trailer with a permanent structure. This project will construct a
label: BODY

text: new, site-built structure of about 1,650-square feet that will provide replacement office space for
label: BODY

text: all of the administrative functions and a small portion of space for functions that are located in
label: BODY

text: two other buildings. The existing administrative trailer has been removed.
label: BODY

text: Construct drainage structures on Utah SR-24 to return the Fremont River into its natural
label: BODY

text: channel: Capitol Reef National Park, in cooperation with the Utah Department of Transportation
label: BODY

text: and the Federal Highways Administration, proposes to construct a set of drainage structures on
label: BODY

text: Utah State Highway 24 to return the Fremont River into its natural channel. The proposed
label: BODY

text: project includes the construction of two bridges, restoration of habitat for the threatened Ute
label: BODY

text: ladies’-tresses orchid, elimination of a manmade waterfall, removal of a parking area near the
label: BODY

text: waterfall, and returning the Fremont River to its natural course in the oxbow.
label: BODY

text: Replace the existing resources trailer and visitor and resources protection (VRP) shack with
label: BODY

text: permanent structures: This project would construct a new, site-built structure that would provide
label: BODY

text: replacement office space for all of the resources management and VRP functions. The existing
label: BODY

text: resources and VRP structures would be removed.
label: BODY

text: Unacceptable Impacts
label: BODY

text: As described in Purpose and Need, the NPS must prevent any activities that would impair park
label: BODY

text: resources and values. The impact threshold at which impairment occurs is not always readily
label: BODY

text: apparent. Therefore, the NPS will apply a standard that offers greater assurance that
label: BODY

text: impairment will not occur. The NPS will do this by avoiding impacts that it determines to be
label: BODY

text: unacceptable. These are impacts that fall short of impairment, but are still not acceptable within
label: BODY

text: a particular park’s environment. Park managers must not allow uses that would cause
label: BODY

text: unacceptable impacts; they must evaluate existing or proposed uses and determine whether the
label: BODY

text: associated impacts on park resources and values are acceptable. Virtually every form of human
label: BODY

text: activity that takes place within a park has some degree of effect on park resources or values,
label: BODY

text: but that does not mean the impact is unacceptable or that a particular use must be disallowed.
label: BODY

text: To determine if unacceptable impact could occur to the resources and values of the parks, the
label: BODY

text: impacts of proposed actions in this environmental assessment were evaluated based on
label: BODY

text: monitoring information, published research, and professional expertise, and compared to the
label: BODY

text: guidance on unacceptable impacts provided in 2006 National Park Service Management Policies
label: BODY

text: 1.4.7.1 that defines unacceptable impacts as impacts that, individually or cumulatively, would:
label: BODY

text: Be inconsistent with a park’s purposes or values, or
label: BODY

text: Resurface the 8-Mile Scenic Drive Road Environmental Assessment
label: BODY

text: Capitol Reef National Park
label: BODY

text: Impede the attainment of a park’s desired future conditions for natural and cultural
label: BODY

text: resources as identified through the park’s planning process, or
label: BODY

text: Create an unsafe or unhealthful environment for visitors or employees, or
label: BODY

text: Diminish opportunities for current or future generations to enjoy, learn about, or be inspired
label: BODY

text: by park resources or values, or
label: BODY

text: Unreasonably interfere with:
label: BODY

text: o Park programs or activities, or
label: BODY

text: o An appropriate use, or
label: BODY

text: o The atmosphere of peace and tranquility, or the natural soundscape maintained in
label: BODY

text: wilderness and natural, historic, or commemorative locations within the park.
label: BODY

text: o NPS concessioner or contractor operations or services.
label: BODY

text: By preventing unacceptable impacts, park managers also ensure that the proposed use of park
label: BODY

text: resources will not conflict with the conservation of those resources. In this manner, the park
label: BODY

text: managers ensure compliance with the Organic Act’s separate mandate to conserve park
label: BODY

text: resources and values.
label: BODY

text: Impairment
label: BODY

text: 2006 National Park Service Management Policies requires analysis of potential effects to
label: BODY

text: determine whether or not actions would impair park resources. The fundamental purpose of the
label: BODY

text: national park system, established by the Organic Act and reaffirmed by the General Authorities
label: BODY

text: Act, as amended, begins with a mandate to conserve park resources and values. National Park
label: BODY

text: Service managers must always seek ways to avoid, or to minimize to the greatest degree
label: BODY

text: practicable, adversely impacting park resources and values.
label: BODY

text: However, the laws do give the National Park Service the management discretion to allow
label: BODY

text: impacts to park resources and values when necessary and appropriate to fulfill the purposes of
label: BODY

text: a park, as long as the impact does not constitute impairment of the affected resources and
label: BODY

text: values. Although Congress has given the National Park Service the management discretion to
label: BODY

text: allow certain impacts within park, that discretion is limited by the statutory requirement that the
label: BODY

text: National Park Service must leave park resources and values unimpaired, unless a particular law
label: BODY

text: directly and specifically provides otherwise. The prohibited impairment is an impact that, in the
label: BODY

text: professional judgment of the responsible National Park Service manager, would harm the
label: BODY

text: integrity of park resources or values. An impact to any park resource or value may, but does not
label: BODY

text: necessarily, constitute an impairment, but an impact would be more likely to constitute an
label: BODY

text: impairment when there is a major or severe adverse effect upon a resource or value whose
label: BODY

text: conservation is:
label: BODY

text: necessary to fulfill specific purposes identified in the establishing legislation or proclamation
label: BODY

text: of the park;
label: BODY

text: key to the natural or cultural integrity of the park; or
label: BODY

text: identified as a goal in the park’s general management plan or other relevant NPS planning
label: BODY

text: documents.
label: BODY

text: Impairment may result from National Park Service activities in managing the park, visitor
label: BODY

text: activities, or activities undertaken by concessioners, contractors, and others operating in the
label: BODY

text: park. A determination on impairment is made in the Environmental Consequences section for
label: BODY

text: Resurface the 8-Mile Scenic Drive Road Environmental Assessment
label: BODY

text: Capitol Reef National Park
label: BODY

text: natural and cultural resource topics.
label: BODY

text: The potential for impairment or unacceptable impacts from the proposed alternatives is provided
label: BODY

text: at the end of this analysis of environmental consequences.

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Impacts of Alternative A (No-Action Alternative)
label: BODY

text: The no-action alternative would have recurrent, short-term, moderate, adverse impacts on the
label: BODY

text: soundscape. Alternative A would maintain the existing circumstances, in which park staff would
label: BODY

text: continue to clear culverts and roadside drainage ditches, stabilize slopes, patch potholes, and
label: BODY

text: complete other isolated repairs as the need arose. Surface flows would continue to adversely
label: BODY

text: affect the road in some locations, and pavement damage from poor subsurface drainage in
label: BODY

text: some locations would require intermittent repairs. The road would continue to deteriorate, and
label: BODY

text: repair operations and their short-term impacts on the soundscape would become more frequent.
label: BODY

text: Typical sound levels from road construction equipment such as trucks, front loaders, pavers,
label: BODY

text: dozers, and graders can be in the range of 63 to 94 dBA at a distance of 100 feet from the
label: BODY

text: sound source. Sound levels from light traffic on paved roads range from 45 to 50 dBA at a
label: BODY

text: Resurface the 8-Mile Scenic Drive Road Environmental Assessment
label: BODY

text: Capitol Reef National Park
label: BODY

text: distance of 100 feet from the roadway, and the sound level on a totally quiet night in a desert
label: BODY

text: would be around 30 decibels (dBA).
label: BODY

text: Noise levels decrease at a rate of approximately 6 dBA per doubling of distance from a noise
label: BODY

text: source. For example, if a sound level were 94 dBA at 100 feet, it would be 88 dBA at 200 feet,
label: BODY

text: and 82 dBA at 400 feet. The rate of decrease is also dependent upon topography and weather
label: BODY

text: conditions, but it is likely that within a mile of the roadway the sound from road repair operations
label: BODY

text: would be greater than the intermittent sounds created by visitors traveling the Scenic Drive.
label: BODY

text: Such sound levels would have a noticeable effect on the visitor experience, disrupting the
label: BODY

text: normally tranquil setting, and on wildlife, impelling some animals to leave or avoid the area.
label: BODY

text: Cumulative Effects:   Impacts to the soundscape were minor and adverse in the short-term
label: BODY

text: during erosion control/bank stabilization measures along State Route 24. Noise from traffic
label: BODY

text: (e.g., heavy equipment, propane trucks, and vans) occurred during the development of the
label: BODY

text: Sleeping Rainbow Ranch as a research facility, creating short-term, moderate, adverse impacts.
label: BODY

text: Noise from outdoor lectures, research activities, and general operations at the research facility
label: BODY

text: now carries to the Pleasant Valley floor, creating long-term, minor, adverse impacts on the
label: BODY

text: soundscape. The work required to replace the existing administration trailer creates short-term,
label: BODY

text: minor, adverse impacts on the soundscape, and replacing the resources trailer will have similar
label: BODY

text: adverse impacts. It is anticipated that constructing drainage structures on Utah SR-24 to return
label: BODY

text: the Fremont River into its natural channel will have short-term, minor, adverse impacts on the
label: BODY

text: soundscape. Those impacts on the soundscape, in combination with the short-term, moderate,
label: BODY

text: adverse impacts of the no action alternative, would have short-term, moderate, adverse,
label: BODY

text: cumulative impacts and long-term, minor, adverse, cumulative impacts on the soundscape.
label: BODY

text: Conclusion:  The no-action alternative would have short-term, moderate, adverse impacts on
label: BODY

text: the soundscape. Cumulative impacts would be short-term, moderate, adverse, and long-term,
label: BODY

text: minor, adverse.
label: BODY

text: Impacts of Alternative B (Preferred Alternative)
label: BODY

text: The preferred alternative would have short-term, moderate, adverse impacts and long-term
label: BODY

text: beneficial impacts on the soundscape. The noise levels from road repair operations would be
label: BODY

text: very noticeable to visitors and would adversely affect wildlife in the surrounding area, but the
label: BODY

text: noise would not have an effect on the regional level. However, the rehabilitation and resurfacing
label: BODY

text: of the entire length of the Scenic Drive would reduce the frequency of periodic repairs. With
label: BODY

text: erosion and slumping of the road shoulders repaired, drainage deficiencies and subgrade
label: BODY

text: deficiencies remedied, and repaving of the road with asphalt concrete or chip-sealing, the need
label: BODY

text: for future repairs would be reduced. Noise associated with such road repairs would be
label: BODY

text: correspondingly reduced.
label: BODY

text: Cumulative Effects:   The cumulative impacts on the soundscape from past, present, and future
label: BODY

text: actions (as discussed above in alternative A), in combination with the short-term, moderate,
label: BODY

text: adverse impacts and long-term beneficial impacts of the preferred alternative, would have short-
label: BODY

text: term, moderate, adverse, and long-term beneficial cumulative impacts.
label: BODY

text: Conclusion:  The preferred alternative would have short-term, moderate, adverse impacts and
label: BODY

text: long-term beneficial impacts on the soundscape. Cumulative impacts would be short-term,
label: BODY

text: moderate, adverse, and long-term beneficial.

label: BODY

text: Alternative A would have long-term, minor, adverse impacts on geology and soils because
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Impacts of Alternative B (Preferred Alternative)
label: BODY

text: Alternative B would have long-term beneficial impacts on geology and soils by reducing erosion,
label: BODY

text: rutting, and soil compaction throughout the length of the Scenic Drive. Drainage culverts would
label: BODY

text: be replaced and cleaned as needed to better convey runoff flows and prevent erosion. Stone
label: BODY

text: armoring would be placed in drainages as needed to prevent erosion and the development of
label: BODY

text: scour holes below culvert outfalls. Vehicle pull-outs would be formalized and rehabilitated
label: BODY

text: throughout the length of the Scenic Drive. Other informal pull-outs would be closed, rehabilitated
label: BODY

text: and revegetated as needed to reduce and prevent erosion, rutting, and compaction along the
label: BODY

text: Scenic Drive.
label: BODY

text: Alternative B would create some long-term minor adverse impacts on geology and soils from
label: BODY

text: widening of the travel lanes and excavation of ditches. Near the Capitol Gorge parking area,
label: BODY

text: from approximately milepost 7.4 to 7.9, the adjacent hillside would be cut back to create 2:1 to
label: BODY

text: 3:1 slopes. Drainage ditches would be cut at the toe of the slope alongside the roadway. The
label: BODY

text: roadway would be widened only slightly, if at all. It is estimated that approximately 2,000 to
label: BODY

text: 2,500 cubic yards of shale, shale residuum soils, and sandstone would be excavated.
label: BODY

text: The subgrade throughout the 8-mile length of the Scenic Drive would be excavated as needed
label: BODY

text: in spot locations, and replaced with appropriate fill material. In isolated locations throughout the
label: BODY

text: length of the Scenic Drive the roadway would be widened by 1 to 2 feet, to provide a consistent
label: BODY

text: road width as much as is feasible.
label: BODY

text: An existing earthen ditch at approximately milepost 1.25, south of the Gifford barn, would be
label: BODY

text: improved to better convey sediment-laden runoff. Options being considered include
label: BODY

text: reconstructing and paving the ditch with a consistent cross section and slope to more easily
label: BODY

text: accommodate mechanical maintenance, or retaining the current native soil ditch while
label: BODY

text: implementing a schedule of more frequent maintenance. The native soil ditch would be
label: BODY

text: reshaped and hardened with compaction as needed. More analysis will be conducted to
label: BODY

text: determine the proper solution. Other ditches throughout the length of the Scenic Drive would be
label: BODY

text: cleaned, realigned, and widened as necessary to properly convey runoff.
label: BODY

text: There would be more beneficial impacts from the reduction of erosion, rutting and compaction,
label: BODY

text: than adverse impacts, and overall, the impacts of alternative B on geology and soils would be
label: BODY

text: long-term beneficial.

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: beneficial cumulative impacts on geology and soils.
label: BODY

text: Conclusion: Alternative B would have long-term beneficial impacts on geology and soils.

text: Impacts of Alternative B (Preferred Alternative)
label: BODY

text: Alternative B would have short-term minor adverse impacts on health and safety. The adverse
label: BODY

text: impacts would occur due to road repair operations, as motorists approach and pass through the
label: BODY

text: construction area. The adverse impacts would be limited to the construction period. During
label: BODY

text: construction, a traffic control plan would be implemented to provide visitors with safe driving
label: BODY

text: conditions during construction. The traffic control plan would include temporary closing of lanes,
label: BODY

text: sequencing of construction events to minimize impacts to traffic, and restricting contractor work.
label: BODY

text: Visitors would be notified of changes in traffic patterns, detours, and traffic delays through the
label: BODY

text: use of signs and public notifications. The Scenic Drive would be completely closed for as much
label: BODY

text: as a month between Grand Wash and the Capitol Gorge parking area, but it would remain
label: BODY

text: passable by administrative and emergency vehicles. All of these actions would be designed to
label: BODY

text: reduce short-term impacts on safety. Routine road maintenance would continue to impact health
label: BODY

text: and safety with noise, delays, and diminished visual quality, but maintenance needs and
label: BODY

text: frequencies would be reduced. With these measures, there would be a minor short-term
label: BODY

text: adverse impact on safety from changes in traffic patterns, construction activities, and continuing
label: BODY

text: routine maintenance on the Scenic Drive.
label: BODY

text: The correction of existing roadway deficiencies and improved safety features would increase
label: BODY

text: safety for motorists on the Scenic Drive. The long-term impacts would be beneficial. The rustic
label: BODY

text: character of the road would be retained, but visitors would be able to drive more safely on the
label: BODY

text: newly surfaced roadway and repaired low water crossings. The improved turning width at the
label: BODY

text: Fruita Campground would provide a safer traffic flow through there.

text: Cumulative Impacts: The effects of other past, present, and future actions (as discussed above
label: BODY

text: in alternative A) would have short-term, minor, adverse impacts and long-term beneficial
label: BODY

text: impacts on health and safety. Those actions, in combination with the short-term minor adverse
label: BODY

text: impacts and beneficial long-term impacts of alternative B, would have short-term minor adverse
label: BODY

text: impacts and beneficial long-term cumulative impacts on health and safety.
label: BODY

text: Conclusion: Alternative B would have short-term minor adverse impacts and beneficial long-
label: BODY

text: term impacts on health and safety. Cumulative impacts would be short-term, minor, adverse and
label: BODY

text: long-term beneficial.

text: Impacts of Alternative B (Preferred Alternative)
label: BODY

text: Alternative B would have short-term minor adverse impacts on visitor use and experience during
label: BODY

text: road repair and rehabilitation activities, and it would have long-term minor adverse impacts
label: BODY

text: associated with maintenance activities. However, rehabilitation and resurfacing of the Scenic
label: BODY

text: Drive would also have long-term beneficial impacts on visitor use and experience.
label: BODY

text: Most of the adverse impacts to visitor use would occur during rehabilitation and resurfacing
label: BODY

text: operations, and would be limited to the construction period. Construction along the roadway
label: BODY

text: would result in minor adverse impacts on visitor use by causing increased levels of noise and
label: BODY

text: dust, diminished visual quality, and delays in traveling the length of the road. Noise and other
label: BODY

text: associated activities would likely cause wildlife to avoid the construction areas, reducing visitors’
label: BODY

text: opportunities for wildlife viewing near the road. Construction would also adversely impact noise
label: BODY

text: levels and the visual experience in the surrounding countryside. Those short- term adverse
label: BODY

text: impacts would be noticeable to visitors, but their effect would be slight.
label: BODY

text: Construction would likely require that the Scenic Drive would be closed between Grand Wash
label: BODY

text: and the Capitol Gorge parking area for as long as a month, creating a short-term moderate
label: BODY

text: adverse impact on visitor use and experience. Visitors would be very aware of the impact, and
label: BODY

text: would likely express an opinion about it.
label: BODY

text: Road maintenance would continue to impact visitor use and experience with noise, delays, and
label: BODY

text: diminished visual quality, but maintenance needs and frequencies would be reduced. Use of
label: BODY

text: stone retaining walls to prevent erosion near the roadway would create a long-term adverse
label: BODY

text: impact to visual quality, by introducing a new and unnatural visual element. The combination of
label: BODY

text: intermittent road maintenance activities, combined with the addition of some new retaining walls
label: BODY

text: would create a minor long-term adverse impact to visitor use and experience.
label: BODY

text: Following construction, the visitor experience would be improved and would benefit from
label: BODY

text: alternative B. Access throughout the length of the Scenic Drive would be improved, because it
label: BODY

text: would be fully paved with asphalt pavement or chip-seal. With subgrade improvements, those
label: BODY

text: segments of the road that are affected by subsidence or slumping would no longer require
label: BODY

text: frequent repairs. Visitors would be able to drive comfortably on the newly surfaced roadway,
label: BODY

text: with increased opportunities to view scenery and wildlife, with less need to focus on road
label: BODY

text: conditions. Paving the parking area at Capitol Gorge would eliminate rutting and the uneven
label: BODY

text: surface there. Access to the comfort station at that parking area would also be improved.

text: CONSULTATION AND COORDINATION
label: H2

text: Internal Scoping
label: BODY

text: Internal scoping was conducted by an interdisciplinary team of professionals from Capitol Reef
label: BODY

text: National Park, Intermountain Region Office, the DSC, and CFLHD. Interdisciplinary team
label: BODY

text: members met at the park on February 10 and 11, 2009, to discuss the purpose and need for the
label: BODY

text: project; existing conditions, and potential alternatives. An environmental screening form was
label: BODY

text: completed by park staff in May 2009 to consider potential effects on park resources and to
label: BODY

text: identify the appropriate NEPA document for analyzing those potential effects. The appropriate
label: BODY

text: NEPA document was identified as an EA. On October 20, 2009 staff from the park, DSC, and
label: BODY

text: CFLHD reviewed conditions along the Scenic Drive again, to consider repair and rehabilitation
label: BODY

text: procedures, potential environmental impacts, and possible mitigation measures. The team also
label: BODY

text: considered past, present, and reasonably foreseeable projects that may have cumulative
label: BODY

text: effects, gathered background information, and discussed public outreach for the project.
label: BODY

text: Agency Consultation
label: BODY

text: In accordance with the Endangered Species Act, the National Park Service contacted the U.S.
label: BODY

text: Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) with regards to federally listed special status species. The
label: BODY

text: USFWS concurred with the NPS opinion that the proposed project is not likely to adversely
label: BODY

text: affect any protected species, and is not likely to adversely modify critical habitat of the Mexican
label: BODY

text: spotted owl. The NPS consultation letter and the USFWS concurrence are included in Appendix
label: BODY

text: A of this EA.
label: BODY

text: In accordance with Section 106 of the National Historic Preservation Act, the NPS provided the
label: BODY

text: Utah SHPO an opportunity to comment on the effects of this project through submittal of
label: BODY

text: separate documentation. A consultation letter was sent to the SHPO by the park on January 22,
label: BODY

text: 2010. On January 28, the SHPO concurred that sites that are eligible for listing in the National
label: BODY

text: Register of Historic Places would not be adversely affected by the proposed project. The
label: BODY

text: consultation letter with signed concurrence by the SHPO is included as Appendix B of this EA.

text: As the nation’s principal conservation agency, the Department of the Interior has the responsibility for
label: BODY

text: most of our nationally owned public lands and natural resources. This includes fostering sound use of
label: BODY

text: our land and water resources; protecting our fish, wildlife, and biological diversity; preserving the
label: BODY

text: environmental and cultural values of our national parks and historic places; and providing for the
label: BODY

text: enjoyment of life through outdoor recreation. The department assesses our energy and mineral
label: BODY

text: resources and works to ensure that their development is in the best interests of all our people by
label: BODY

text: encouraging stewardship and citizen participation in their care. The department also has a major
label: BODY
